attacks.hit: 15 damage, and the target is vulnerable (save ends)

extras.name: Natural 14+
extras.description: The target takes 12 extra damage from a wing buffet.

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The target takes 20 extra damage from a claw strike.

extras.name: Natural 19+
extras.description: The dragon can make a treasury master attack as a free action

attacks.name: C:Treasury master
attacks.attack: +16 vs. MD (the nearby non-confused enemy with de most true magic items)
attacks.hit: 30 psychic damage, and the target is confused (save ends)

attacks.name: Precise breath
attacks.attack: +16 vs. PD (1d4+1 nearby enemies, or 1 enemy)
attacks.hit: 50 fire damage, and 15 ongoing fire damage; OR 170 fire damage, and 30 ongoing fire damage if used against a single enemy

extras.name: Natural 18+
extras.description: If the breath targeted multiple enemies, the target takes 25 ongoing fire damage instead of 15. If the breath targeted a single enemy, the target takes 60 ongoing fire damage instead of 30.

traits.name: Lair
traits.description: If the dragon is in his lair, it has +1 to AC.

traits.name: Greathoard rage
traits.description: When an enemy scores a critical hit against the greathoard elder while it’s in its lair, the elder can reroll one of its missed attacks each round (cumulative) as its hoard sings a song of carnage to it.

traits.name: Intermittent breath
traits.description: A greathoard elder can use precise breath 1d4 +1 times per battle, but never two turns in a row.

specials.name: Iconic comparisons
specials.description: The dragon is enamored/envious of the icons with the greatest hoards. For each PC who has at least one positive or conflicted relationship point with one or more of those icons, the greathoard elder gains an extra use of treasury master this battle.

extras.name: Natural even miss
extras.description: The target pops free from all enemies engaged with it and is vulnerable to all attacks (save ends).

traits.name: Leaping bite
traits.description: The green bulette gains a +3 bonus to attack and damage with its first attack each battle.

traits.name: Into the earth
traits.description: The first time each round an attack hits the bulette, it can choose to hunker down as a free action. If it does, it gains a +3 bonus to AC and PD until the start of its next turn. Force attacks and opportunity attacks don’t trigger this ability. If the green bulette hunkers down while it’s moving (for example, from a readied action), its movement ends that turn.

traits.name: Blood-frenzy escalator
traits.description: While at least one creature in the battle is staggered or unconscious, the bulette gains a bonus to its attacks and damage equal to the escalation die but can’t use into the earth. Creatures that have no blood (constructs, oozes, plant creatures, etc.) don’t trigger this ability.

traits.name: Occasional burrower
traits.description: Like all bulettes, the green bulette can burrow. While above ground, it prefers to move slowly on the surface and rely on its plant- and soil-covered shell to stay hidden until it attacks.

attacks.name: Needle teeth
attacks.hit: 20 poison damage, and 15 ongoing poison damage

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The target becomes vulnerable to poison damage until the end of the battle. Creatures that resist poison damage ignore this effect.

extras.name: Crit
extras.description: The target loses all its resistances and is weakened until the end of its next turn.

extras.name: Limited use
extras.description: 1/battle, but missing with the attack doesn’t expend it.

attacks.name: C: Poison cloud
attacks.attack: +14 vs. PD (1d3 nearby enemies in a group)

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The crit range for this attack expands by 1 (to a maximum of 16+).

traits.name: Hallucinogenic exhalation
traits.description: The first time this greenscale spineback becomes staggered, each nearby enemy must roll a save. If it fails, it’s confused and takes 10 ongoing poison damage (save ends both). Enemies who resist poison are immune to this effect.

traits.name: Resist poison 16+
traits.description: When a poison attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 16+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

specials.name: Elf killer
specials.description: The spineback hates elves, and its crit range expands by 1 against them.

specials.name: Tail whip
specials.description: The dragonic deals 2d6 extra damage to a target it misses with a melee attack.

specials.name: Toxic skin
specials.description: This spineback is not so much scaly as slimy like a rare toxic frog. When an enemy makes an unarmed attack against it or otherwise grapples with the dragonic, that enemy takes 2d6 poison damage.

specials.name: Limited flight
specials.description: At the start of each turn, roll a /r d6. If the result is less than or equal to the escalation die, the dragonic gains flight as a move action during its turns thanks to a pair of wings it unfurls from its back. The flight tends to be more power-flapping or gliding from one place to another rather than hovering. Flamewings who also have limited flight prefer to use their burning wings to fly in combat wherever possible, resorting to their physical wings only if needed.

specials.name: Blood of the wyrm
specials.description: This dragonic displays traits of its forebears, the mighty wyrms. Roll a /r d10 and consult the random dragon ability table, or choose one of the first ten options that looks likely to shape the story or battle.

extras.name: First failed save
extras.description: The ongoing poison damage increases by 2.

extras.name: Second failed save
extras.description: The target is also weakened (save ends both).

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The target is partially blinded and takes a –2 penalty to attacks and defenses until the end of its next turn.

traits.name: Superior camouflage
traits.description: The wild stalker’s scales naturally change to blend with its surroundings, allowing it to hide in plain sight and making checks to detect it take a –5 penalty. When it attacks from concealment without being seen first, the target is vulnerable to its attack. It can regain its camouflage by moving out of direct sight and hiding (hard DC to spot).

traits.name: Resist poison 14+
traits.description: When a poison attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 14+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

specials.description: At the start of each turn, roll a /r d6. The flight tends to be more power-flapping or gliding from one place to another rather than hovering. Flamewings who also have limited flight prefer to use their burning wings to fly in combat wherever possible, resorting to their physical wings only if needed.

specials.description: This dragonic displays traits of its forebears, the mighty wyrms. Roll a /r d10 and consult the random dragon ability table, or choose one of the first ten options that looks likely to shape the story or battle.

extras.name: Natural 18+
extras.description: The target is dazed until the end of its next turn.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: Death shades can hover and fly about easily.

traits.name: Partial phasing
traits.description: As a quick action, a death shade can pass through a small or narrow solid object or pop free from all enemies engaged with it. When a creature intercepts a death shade, that creature takes 25 negative energy damage.

traits.name: Shadow of death
traits.description: A death shade gains a +2 attack bonus against the last creature in the battle to roll a death save. Death shades specifically target dying or helpless creatures unless somebody is actively attacking them while standing over the body of the dying or helpless creature.

extras.name: Both attacks hit the same target
extras.description: Until the end of its next turn, the target is affected by the reaver’s *fear aura* even if it has more than 72 hp.

traits.name: Phasing
traits.description:
While the escalation die is odd, the reaver takes no damage and suffers no effects from attacks with natural attack rolls less than 18+ (or 16+ for attacks that deal holy damage). It does take full damage and effects from attacks that are able to affect it.

While phasing, the reaver can move but creatures can’t intercept it, and it can travel through solid objects but not end its turn in them. In addition, while phasing the reaver can’t attack (including opportunity attacks) or affect the physical world except in the following way: When an enemy starts its turn engaged with the phased reaver, it takes 25 negative energy damage. 

The reaver can also using phasing outside of battle, but only for a short time.

traits.name: Call upon death shades
traits.description: Until the reaver drops to 0 hp, when one of its living (not undead or construct) enemies or non-mook allies rolls a death save or dies, a death shade enters the battle. Death shades act immediately after the reaver in initiative order.

traits.name: Death aura
traits.description: When the escalation die is 6+, all normal saves made during the battle become hard saves (16+).

traits.name: Fear aura
traits.description: While engaged with this creature, enemies with 72 hp or fewer are dazed and do not add the escalation die to their attacks.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: Reavers ignore the bonds of gravity while they’re phasing.

traits.name: Marked by death
traits.description: When a creature disengages or moves away from a reaver that’s phasing, that creature is vulnerable to negative energy until the end of its next turn.

traits.name: Unholy backlash
traits.description: Deal 3d10 negative energy damage to any creature that targets the gruesome reaver with an attack that deals holy damage.

extras.name: Natural 14+
extras.description: The hag triggers one hag ability as a free action.

extras.name: Natural 18+
extras.description: The hag triggers two hag abilities as a free action (can’t be the same ability twice).

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The attack roll also targets a second different enemy of the hag’s choice (but not a third with another 16+).

extras.name: Natural 18+
extras.description: As above, and the attack roll also targets a third different enemy of the hag’s choice (but not a fourth with another 18+).

traits.name: Death curse
traits.description: Each hag can lay a curse upon the one who ends its horrible life. After dropping to 0 hit points, a hag always lingers long enough to pronounce the words of the curse. (See Death Curses.)

traits.name: Delusionist
traits.description: All hags have the ability to twist the perceptions of others. If the hag has a short time to prepare, it can hide a small hut, disguise a volunteer or captive as a monster, disguise itself as a harmless peasant woman, etc. A DC 30 skill check is required to overcome the delusion and see the truth of it (if a player gives a reason for not trusting what their character sees; perhaps add subtle clues toward that end). The magic fades as soon as the hag enters combat.

traits.name: Fear
traits.description: While engaged with this creature, enemies with 30 hp or fewer are dazed (-4 attack) and do not add the escalation die to their attacks.

attacks.name: Spontaneous metamorphosing limbs
attacks.hit: 110 damage, and the hagunemnon can make a spontaneous metamorphosing limbs attack against a different target as a free action

extras.name: Natural 19+
extras.description: The target starts making last gasp saves. On the fourth failure, it becomes a shapeless ooze.

traits.name: Diminishing limbs
traits.description: With each subsequent hit after the first, spontaneous metamorphosing limbs deals 20 less damage. The hagunemnon also doesn’t gain any extra attacks when it makes a basic attack.

traits.name: Dimension hop
traits.description: As a move action when the escalation die is odd, the hagunemnon can teleport nearby or far away to a location it can see.

traits.name: Resist psychic 18+
traits.description: When a psychic attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 18+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

traits.name: Shapechange
traits.description: As a standard action, the hagunemnon can change its form to that of any large or medium creature, or back to its own shape. Seeing through the shapechange requires a DC 25 skill check.

specials.name: Madness aura
specials.description: When a creature is engaged with the hagunemnon at the start of its turn, it takes 4d10 psychic damage. If it takes 31 or more damage this way during a single turn, it’s also confused until the start of its next turn.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: One nearby lower-level mook makes an attack as a free action.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The half-orc commander gains 20 temporary hit points.

traits.name: Orcish command
traits.description: When a nearby ally of the half-orc commander scores a critical hit, that ally can roll a save against a save ends effect as a free action.

extras.name: Natural odd miss
extras.description: The tribal champion heals 5 hp.

extras.name: Natural even miss
extras.description: 10 damage.

traits.name: Tribal rage
traits.description: When the escalation die is even, a tribal champion can roll two  for each melee attack roll it makes and use the result it prefers. If both dice are 11+, the melee attack is a critical hit.

extras.name: Natural 16+ hit
extras.description: Target is weakened and hampered until the end of its next turn.

extras.name: Limited use
extras.description: Only when the hallowed gargoyle starts its turn flying and ends its turn engaged on the ground.

attacks.name: (Each hallowed gargoyle has one of the following attacks)

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: One nearby ally can roll a save against a save ends effect. If no allies are affected by a save ends effect, one nearby ally can make a basic attack as a free action.

extras.name: Limited use
extras.description: 1/battle

extras.name: Limited use
extras.description: 1/battle

attacks.name: C: Denunciation
attacks.attack: +11 vs. MD (1 enemy that has attacked the hallowed gargoyle this battle)

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The target is hampered (save ends)

extras.name: Limited use
extras.description: 1/battle

traits.name: Halo
traits.description: The first time the hallowed gargoyle is hit by an attack against MD, reroll the attack with a -2 attack penalty. (Sometimes the halo sputters, so if you forget to use it the first time, use the reroll later in the battle.)

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: Hallowed gargoyles can fly, but not gracefully. Mid-air, they take a -2 penalty to all their defenses, and it takes them two move actions to get airborne unless they can launch from above.

traits.name: Rocky hide
traits.description: The hallowed gargoyle has resist damage 12+ against attacks targeting AC.

specials.name: Mirrored aggression
specials.description: Hallowed gargoyles have some ability to sense intentions and a larger capacity to react appropriately! PCs with a negative or conflicted relationship with the Religious Icon are vulnerable to all the hallowed gargoyles’ attacks.

specials.name: Statues, statues, everywhere
specials.description: Because they look so much like statues, and because most of the things that look like hallowed gargoyles are statues, hallowed gargoyles are capable of springing a surprise on inattentive PCs. When there’s a chance of such an ambush, give the PCs a normal skill check (DC 20 at champion-tier, DC 25 at epic tier) to notice the gargoyles waking and avoid being surprised (13th Age core rulebook, page 164).

extras.name: Natural 16-17
extras.description: The target is hampered (easy save ends, 6+).

extras.name: Natural 18-19
extras.description: The target is weakened instead of hampered (easy save ends, 6+).

traits.name: Cull
traits.description: The harpy gains a +5 bonus to attack and damage with this attack against any enemy suffering from any fiendish song effect.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: Flight

extras.description: Both the zombie and the target take 3d10 damage.

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The target takes 20 psychic damage.

traits.name: Death spasms
traits.description: When a headless zombie drops to 0 hp, it flails with its fists and makes a mouthless cry attack as a free action before it dies.

traits.name: Inevitable hunger
traits.description: When a creature tries to affect the zombie’s attack, such as forcing a reroll or applying a penalty, it must roll a normal save; on a failure, the effect is negated.

specials.name: Baleful aura
specials.description: While nearby a headless zombie, when a creature would heal, it only heals half the normal hit points.

specials.name: Necrotic supremacy
specials.description: When the escalation die increases to 6, each headless zombie in the battle is restored to maximum hit points, including the dead ones.

traits.description: When you choos to add the escalation die to an attack against a hell imp, the imp automatically hits with it next needign taunt attack this battle, and the target taes 2d6 extra psychic damage.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: Hell imps are capable of impressive feats of aerial agility, but only when teir lives depends on it.

traits.name: Vanish
traits.description: Once per battle as a move action, a hell imp can become invisible, pop free from all enemies engaged with it, move away somwhere nearby, and then reappear.

traits.name: Free-form ability - Provoke
traits.description: Hell imps are as capable as you might expect at handling social situations, sneaking, noticing spies, and the like. Their special talent is provocation. They can talk their associates into all sorts of extreme emotions and imprudent behavior. Likewise, they can probably goad PCs into losing their cool.

specials.name: Potent venom
specials.description: The stinging tail attack deals 3 extra ongoing poison damage (11 total), but the target must succeed on two saves (one for ongoing and one for weakened).

attacks.name: Blazing pounce
attacks.hit: 13 damage, and the hellcat pops free from the target and uses its move action to engage a nearby enemy. It can’t be intercepted during this movement. It then makes a second attack that also deals 10 ongoing fire damage on a hit.

extras.name: Limited use
extras.description: The hellcat must have its move action available to use *blazing pounce*.

traits.name: Devil’s due (stalker)
traits.description: When you choose to add the escalation die to an attack against a hellcat, during its next turn it gains a cumulative +2 bonus to attack if it’s invisible. Otherwise, it gains a non-cumulative +2 bonus to all defenses until the start of its next turn as its form blurs.

traits.name: Fire fur
traits.description: When an enemy is engaged with the hellcat at the start of its turn, that enemy takes 5 fire damage.

traits.name: Invisible
traits.description: While in bright light, the hellcat is invisible; attacks against it have a 50% miss chance.

traits.name: Resist fire 13+

Fire attacks that target an enemy engaged with the hellcat gain:

Natural 16+: The target takes 5 extra fire damage.

extras.description: The hellwarped pops free from each enemy engaged with it after making its claws attacks, then moves to a nearby enemy as a free action and makes this attack.

traits.description: As creatures created by the energies of hellholes, hellwarped beasts are usually also affected by powers that affect demons. GM, it’s your call. In exchange, feel free to allow the hellwarped to deal fire, cold, acid, lightning, or thunder damage with its aberrant attacks.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: Hellwasps are adroit fliers that can hover and even fly backward.

specials.name: Lethal injection
specials.description: The save versus the stinger’s ongoing acid damage is a normal save (11+) instead of an easy save.

traits.name: Any hit
traits.description: The demon can grab the target if it isn’t already grabbing a creature. The grabbed foe can’t move except to teleport, pop free, or attempt to disengage, and disengage attempts take a -5 penalty unless the creature hit the hezrou with an attack that turn.

traits.name: Strong grasp
traits.description: The hezrou gains a +4 attack bonus against any enemy it is grabbing.

traits.name: Demonic stench
traits.description: While engaged with this creature, enemies with 84 hp or fewer are dazed (-4 attack) and do not add the escalation die to their attacks.

specials.name: Abyssal sergeant
specials.description: Lower-level non-mook demons nearby the hezrou deal damage equal to their level when they miss with an attack.

specials.name: Stab this now
specials.description: The hezrou’s allies gain a +4 attack bonus against any creature it is grabbing.

traits.description: Once per battle as a move action, the oread can pull one creature currently overcome by its hard words attack under the ground into an embrace with a part of its consciousness. The oread’s physical form remains above ground and continues to battle. The target remains underground, taking no actions except to bond with the oread and telepathically reveal its secrets to the oread until it saves. traits.name: Bound hauntings
traits.description:
Most ghosts are bound to an area, usually the area of their death. This ability won’t come up much in play, but it does make it seem likely that ghosts can be easier to get away from than other monsters. Move far enough fast enough and the ghost returns to the area it’s bound to. Occasionally festivals for the dead or other rituals can call bound ghosts from their hauntings, but those are unusual and temporary circumstances.

Exceptions: There may be ghosts that are bound to people, or events, or phenomena that travel. There might even be ghosts that aren’t bound to anything, but at that stage there are several other questions that surface and odd magical, iconic, or unique intervention seems likely.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description:
Most ghosts fly, though some may be quite slow, seeming to drift or walking on air. Ghosts that fly in unusual ways will be flagged with their own abilities.

Exceptions: Not all ghosts fly. Some seem constrained to act much like they acted when they were alive, and flying wasn’t part of their life package.

traits.name: Unnatural touch
traits.description:
Many ghosts can alter the temperature of their environment to more closely match the underworld or afterlife that they’ve so far evaded. Sometimes that’s icy cold, sometimes that’s burning hot, and sometimes it’s just kind of normal, which would go unnoticed unless the ghost is somewhere abnormal!

Exceptions: This is more of a special effect of ghost stories than part of a creature’s combat abilities, and you can safely ignore it unless you find telling moments when it adds to the game.

traits.name: Psychic duel
traits.description:
A psychic duel occurs when the intellect assassin hits with an insidious domination attack against a creature. At the start of the creature’s next turn, it must make an Intelligence skill check and can use a background that applies to psychic ability (if any). The result of this check determines that creature’s status until the start of its next turn. To maintain the psychic duel, the assassin must spend a move action each turn.

Psychic Duel Result: Status

  • 15 or less: The creature is confused until the end of its turn. It also can’t make opportunity attacks until the start of its next turn and takes a –2 penalty to its next psychic duel check.
  • 16–22: The creature is pressured—it takes a –2 penalty to attacks against any enemy except the assassin (dueling opponent).
  • 23–27: The creature steadies itself and can use a move action this turn to escape the psychic duel. If the creature chooses not to (or can’t) escape the duel, it gains a +2 bonus to its next psychic duel check.
  • 28+: As 23–27, but the creature takes advantage and gains a +4 bonus to its next psychic duel check instead of +2. In addition, the assassin takes a –2 penalty to attack rolls that target other creatures.

traits.description: When a lemure is targeted by an attack against MD, it ignores any effects of the attack and only takes damage from it. For each 6, one of them reassembles its horrid self and stumbles back into the melee that turn (add 13 hit points to the mob’s hp total). To make sure a downed lemure is truly dead, an attacker can spend an additional 7 damage of the total dealt to finish the job instead of carrying that damage over to another lemure in the mob. Expending the right sort of limited-use power, such as a daily spell, might also keep a number of downed lemures totally dead. Once the last member of the mob drops, stop rolling to see if lemures rise up.

traits.name: Ghostly
traits.description: This creature has resist damage 14+ to all damage except holy damage. A ghost can move through solid objects, but can’t end its turn inside them.

traits.name: Fear-boosters
traits.description: While there are three or more lesser haunting mooks in a battle, the fear abilities of their allies affect enemies with half again as many hit points as usual. (For example, a 3rd level hungrymouth ghost normally has a fear threshold of 15 hit points. When there are three or more lesser haunting mooks in the battle, the hungrymouth ghost’s fear threshold bumps up to 22 hit points.)

traits.name: Bound hauntings
traits.description:
Most ghosts are bound to an area, usually the area of their death. This ability won’t come up much in play, but it does make it seem likely that ghosts can be easier to get away from than other monsters. Move far enough fast enough and the ghost returns to the area it’s bound to. Occasionally festivals for the dead or other rituals can call bound ghosts from their hauntings, but those are unusual and temporary circumstances.

Exceptions: There may be ghosts that are bound to people, or events, or phenomena that travel. There might even be ghosts that aren’t bound to anything, but at that stage there are several other questions that surface and odd magical, iconic, or unique intervention seems likely.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description:
Most ghosts fly, though some may be quite slow, seeming to drift or walking on air. Ghosts that fly in unusual ways will be flagged with their own abilities.

Exceptions: Not all ghosts fly. Some seem constrained to act much like they acted when they were alive, and flying wasn’t part of their life package.

traits.name: Unnatural touch
traits.description:
Many ghosts can alter the temperature of their environment to more closely match the underworld or afterlife that they’ve so far evaded. Sometimes that’s icy cold, sometimes that’s burning hot, and sometimes it’s just kind of normal, which would go unnoticed unless the ghost is somewhere abnormal!

Exceptions: This is more of a special effect of ghost stories than part of a creature’s combat abilities, and you can safely ignore it unless you find telling moments when it adds to the game.

traits.name: Bound hauntings
traits.description:
Most ghosts are bound to an area, usually the area of their death. This ability won’t come up much in play, but it does make it seem likely that ghosts can be easier to get away from than other monsters. Move far enough fast enough and the ghost returns to the area it’s bound to. Occasionally festivals for the dead or other rituals can call bound ghosts from their hauntings, but those are unusual and temporary circumstances.

Exceptions: There may be ghosts that are bound to people, or events, or phenomena that travel. There might even be ghosts that aren’t bound to anything, but at that stage there are several other questions that surface and odd magical, iconic, or unique intervention seems likely.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description:
Most ghosts fly, though some may be quite slow, seeming to drift or walking on air. Ghosts that fly in unusual ways will be flagged with their own abilities.

Exceptions: Not all ghosts fly. Some seem constrained to act much like they acted when they were alive, and flying wasn’t part of their life package.

traits.name: Unnatural touch
traits.description:
Many ghosts can alter the temperature of their environment to more closely match the underworld or afterlife that they’ve so far evaded. Sometimes that’s icy cold, sometimes that’s burning hot, and sometimes it’s just kind of normal, which would go unnoticed unless the ghost is somewhere abnormal!

Exceptions: This is more of a special effect of ghost stories than part of a creature’s combat abilities, and you can safely ignore it unless you find telling moments when it adds to the game.

traits.name: Special Virtues
traits.description:
Each marble golem is infused with two virtues—magical properties that relate to the emotion or feeling incorporated into the sculpture as its dominant theme. Choose two virtues from the list below, or for a unique marble golem, invent your own.

  1. Awe (fear effect): While nearby the golem, enemies with 40 hp or fewer are dazed (–4 attack) and do not add the escalation die to their attacks.
  2. Beauty: The first time each enemy attacks the marble golem this battle, it must roll a normal save; on a failure, the attack takes a –6 penalty.
  3. Courage: While staggered, the marble golem adds the escalation die to its attack rolls.
  4. Endurance: When the marble golem rolls a natural 1–5 with an attack roll, it heals 1d10 hit points per point on the escalation die. (It was checking for damage and got distracted.)
  5. Hatred: When an enemy is staggered by the marble golem’s attack, that enemy takes 4d10 extra damage.
  6. Patience: Each turn, the marble golem can use one standard action to gain a +2 bonus to all defenses until the start of its next turn. If it does, it gains an extra standard action during its next turn.
  7. Protection: When the marble golem rolls a natural 16+ with an attack, decrease the escalation die by 1.
  8. Strength: The marble golem’s melee attacks now deal half damage on a miss.

traits.name: Ghostly
traits.description: This creature has resist damage 14+ to all damage except holy damage. A ghost can move through solid objects, but can’t end its turn inside them.

traits.name: Bound hauntings
traits.description:
Most ghosts are bound to an area, usually the area of their death. This ability won’t come up much in play, but it does make it seem likely that ghosts can be easier to get away from than other monsters. Move far enough fast enough and the ghost returns to the area it’s bound to. Occasionally festivals for the dead or other rituals can call bound ghosts from their hauntings, but those are unusual and temporary circumstances.

Exceptions: There may be ghosts that are bound to people, or events, or phenomena that travel. There might even be ghosts that aren’t bound to anything, but at that stage there are several other questions that surface and odd magical, iconic, or unique intervention seems likely.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description:
Most ghosts fly, though some may be quite slow, seeming to drift or walking on air. Ghosts that fly in unusual ways will be flagged with their own abilities.

Exceptions: Not all ghosts fly. Some seem constrained to act much like they acted when they were alive, and flying wasn’t part of their life package.

traits.name: Unnatural touch
traits.description:
Many ghosts can alter the temperature of their environment to more closely match the underworld or afterlife that they’ve so far evaded. Sometimes that’s icy cold, sometimes that’s burning hot, and sometimes it’s just kind of normal, which would go unnoticed unless the ghost is somewhere abnormal!

Exceptions: This is more of a special effect of ghost stories than part of a creature’s combat abilities, and you can safely ignore it unless you find telling moments when it adds to the game.

specials.description: The phantomaton is armed with a farming implement, and once per battle can make an *iron hoe* attack as a quick action.

specials.name: Built to last (beast type)
specials.description: This phantomaton has been built with sturdier materials than other phantomatons: it has +2 AC and 20 extra hp.

specials.name: Built-in spike-thrower (guard type)
specials.description: The phantomaton has a ranged weapon built directly into its body, and can make a *spike-thrower* attack.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The spider can make a rummage and filch attack against the target as a free action, even if the target isn’t staggered.

attacks.name: Rummage and filch
attacks.hit: the phase spider steals a random true magic item from the target (see below).

traits.name: Phasing abilities
traits.description: As long as it didn’t just return from being out of phase, at the start of the phase spider’s turn, roll a d6 to see which of its phase and teleport abilities it can access that turn. The spider doesn’t have to use the available ability and can attack normally, if it wishes.
Short teleport—As a move action, the spider can teleport anywhere it can see nearby.
Long teleport—As a move action, the spider can teleport anywhere it can see nearby or far away.

Phase out—As a move action, the spider can remove itself from the battlefield, returning on its next initiative turn anywhere it chooses nearby. It doesn’t get to make a phase roll at the start of its next turn though.

Teleport away—If the spider has stolen at least one magic item, as a move action it can teleport back to its lair, or to its master if it has one. It leaves the battle. If it hasn’t stolen an item yet, it won’t leave and can use its choice of the other abilities this turn.

traits.name: Stolen items
traits.description: If the spider is slain before it leaves battle, all items stolen from the party are recovered. If a  roll results in a 20, other magic items are found.

attacks.name: Fiendish weapon
attacks.hit: 140 damage, and until the end of the battle the target takes a -2 penalty to attacks, defenses, and level-based  rolls. Hit points, feats, weapon damage, and other level-based benefits don’t change. (The penalty isn’t cumulative.)

extras.name: Natural 11+
extras.description: The pit fiend can make an entangling tail attack against a different target as a free action.

attacks.name: Entangling tail
attacks.hit: 40 damage, and the target is hampered until the end of its next turn or until the pit fiend makes another entangling tail attack.

attacks.name: R: Burst of hellfire
attacks.attack: +19 vs. PD (up to 3 nearby or far away enemies in a group)

attacks.name: C: Black utterance of denial
attacks.attack: +19 vs. MD (each enemy engaged with the pit fiend)
attacks.hit: The target is hampered until the end of its next turn

traits.name: Both attacks hit
traits.description: The pit fiend can use fiendish vigor as a free action.

traits.name: Devil’s due (Menace)
traits.description: When you choose to add the escalation die to an attack against a pit fiend, the escalation die does not increase at the start of the next round. Special circumstances and PC powers can still increase it.

traits.name: Fiendish vigor
traits.description: As a standard action, the pit fiend can heal 300 hp and roll a save against each ongoing effect on it. It can use fiendish vigor up to five times per battle.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: Amidst wind and flames, a pit fiend can fly with surprising agility.

traits.name: Resist fire 13+
traits.description: When a fire attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 13+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

specials.name: Cloak of fire
specials.description: When a creature is engaged with the pit fiend at the start of its turn, that creature takes 20 fire damage.

traits.name: Mob attack
traits.description: The crit range for pit-spawn orcs is 17+. Whenever a pit-spawn orc scores a critical hit, each pit-spawn orc mook in the battle gains a +1 cumulative bonus to damage until the end of the battle.

specials.name: Boiling rage
specials.description: When an enemy engaged with the orc hits it with an attack, the enemy takes 4 damage as the orc bites and claws it back.

traits.name: Fluttering
traits.description: The pixie knight flies, but never too far from the ground.

traits.name: Dancing mote
traits.description: The pixie knight can’t be intercepted and doesn’t provoke opportunity attacks by moving.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: Add a new podling into the battle in a random location.

traits.name: Release the pods
traits.description: Once per battle when the pixie pod rolls a natural even hit with peripheral summoning, it adds a number of podlings into the battle equal to the escalation die instead of only one.

traits.name: Immobile
traits.description: Although its podlings occasionally pick up and move it around out of combat, in battle the pixie pod can’t move and is stuck except for its teleport ability.

traits.name: Lost opportunity
traits.description: This creature can’t make opportunity attacks.

traits.name: Lurching teleport
traits.description: Once per battle as a move action, the pixie-pod can teleport to a nearby location. But its control sucks. The teleport goes in a random direction. Roll it using a d8 for direction.

traits.name: Magical concealment
traits.description: As long as one or more of its podlings are nearby, the pixie pod is invisible and extremely difficult to even detect. A PC who wants to locate the pixie-pod must spend a standard action searching and succeed at a DC 25 skill check using Wisdom. Backgrounds connected to plants and the wilderness help normally, and general searching skills and magic talents might help a bit but not at full strength. Once located, the plant can be attacked like a normal invisible creature. When it teleports, however, it must be located all over again.

traits.name: Start with mooks
traits.description: The pixie pod is normally accompanied by five active podlings that don’t count toward the total when building a battle with the pod. Additional podlings do count, however.

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The pixie warrior can make a madness attack against the target as a free action.

attacks.name: Enchanted boswhot
attacks.hit: 4 psychic damage, and the pixie warrior can make a madness attack against the target as a free action.

attacks.name: Madness
attacks.hit: The target is maddened until the end of the pixie's next turn.

traits.name: Maddened
traits.description:
The first thing the creature does on its turn is use a standard action to make a display of power that has no practical benefit. The GM chooses the attack, spell, or other power, which should be the most powerful one the character has, preferably a daily. The target expends the power in a great show of prowess, aimed for display rather than effect. Wizards cast their fireballs into the sky, monks demonstrate flawless form while shadow-boxing, and clerics bless the very stones underfoot instead of allies.

When the madness effect gets old, substitute any of the following effects, by choice or at random:

  1. You love pixies and hate those who threaten them. The target is confused until the end of the pixie’s next turn.
  2. Brains knocked loose. The target takes 4 psychic damage each time it takes an action (save ends; yes that could be 3 times per round or more).
  3.  Reality bender. The target takes 5 ongoing psychic damage. Each time the target fails the save, the ongoing damage increases by 5, cumulative.
  4. Massive attack on the unconscious mind. The target chooses one: either let the onslaught slam its mind (take 15 psychic damage), or steel its mind against the onslaught (stunned until the end of the pixie’s next turn).
  5. Compulsion to dance. The target takes 5 ongoing psychic damage (no save) until it spends a standard action to dance maniacally. Dancing ends all such ongoing damage, even if the target has been hit multiple times with this effect.
  6. Pacifism. The target can’t attack until the end of the pixie’s next turn.

traits.name: Dazzling lights
traits.description: During battle, pixies fill the air with the light and sound of countless flashy illusions. The effects are disorienting enough that the PCs don’t get to add the escalation die to their attacks.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: Pixies make flying look like a lot of fun.

traits.name: Invisibility
traits.description: When an enemy attacks a pixie and misses, the pixie turns invisible until the start of its next turn (even if it makes opportunity attacks). A pixie can also turn invisible as a standard action, in which case the invisibility still lasts until the start of its next turn.

traits.name: 8. Magenta
traits.description: The target is transported into the future. Remove that creature from play, returning it to the battle in (or near) its previous location at the end of its next turn. No time seems to pass for the target while it’s gone.

traits.description: When a limited attack (not an at-will attack) targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 16+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

traits.name: Warp
traits.description: “Yellow hair,” “Afraid of spiders,” “Prefers white wine to red,” or “Tattoo of a halfling on left bicep.” These personal traits are shuffled and randomly distributed equally by the GM after the battle is over. Whichever trait each player receives is now true for their character as well as for the character of the player who wrote it down (unless there has somehow turned out to be a swap…). These traits don’t alter game mechanics (feats, powers, backgrounds, icon relationships, attributes, bonuses, etc.). They are personal details that have been warped and scrambled by the prismatic ogre mage’s magic.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The target is swallowed whole if it's smaller than the worm (see below)

extras.name: Natural 1-5
extras.description: The worm takes 10 damage (but it still deals miss damage on a 2-5)

traits.name: Swallow whole
traits.description:
While a creature is swallowed whole, it takes 7d10 acid damage at the start of its turn and is stuck, hampered, and unable to attack or affect anything outside the worm’s stomach (and vice-versa). Most teleport abilities don’t work because you’re hampered and you can’t see the location out of the worm you want to teleport to. There are two ways out.

  • Cut your way out: Deal 40 damage to the worm with a single attack and you can cut your way out. All edged or bladed weapons are reduced to d6 damage dice (at most) inside the worm’s gullet, so good luck. At least you’ll be damaging the worm attacking it from within.
  • Get upchucked: While the worm is staggered, you can use a standard action to try and crawl out of its mouth. Roll a hard save (16+); on a success, the worm vomits you out and spits you somewhere nearby. The worm also vomits out all creatures it has swallowed when it drops to 0 hp.

traits.name: Burrow
traits.description: As the standard monster ability

specials.name: Larval feeding
specials.description: The worm's stomach also includes a mob of larval mook (purple larvae or parasitic lightning beetles). Feel free to add this nastier special if a PC acts dismissive about the possibility of being swallowed by the worm.

specials.name: Resist most energy damage 16+
specials.description:
Purple worms generate weird energy resistances thanks to underworld radiation and their odd diets. Roll a 2d8, in secret, to determine what energy types the worm is not resistant to. The PCs probably have to find out what energy works best against the worm the hard way, though you might have mercy and allow a DC 35 Wisdom skill check to figure out what energy types work against the worm.

1: acid; 2: cold; 3: fire; 4: lightning; 5: thunder; 6: holy; 7: negative energy; 8: poison.

traits.name: Spreading flames
traits.description: Any enemy of the salamander who is not taking ongoing fire damage, and who during any point on their turn is next to or engaged with a creature taking ongoing fire damage, must roll a save (11+) or take 50 ongoing fire damage.

traits.name: Escalating inferno
traits.description: If the salamander is in an area with flames, lava, or that it has set on fire, it gets to use the escalation die, adding it to its attack rolls. Even when not fighting in such an environment, a salamander attacked with a spell or attack that deals fire damage gets to use the escalation die until the end of its next turn, or longer if it’s a powerful or lingering spell. Avoid casting fireball in battle with a salamander!

traits.name: Resist fire 16+
traits.description: Fire attacks against the salamander must roll a natural 16+ attack roll or the attack does half damage. Whether or not such an attack hits, see *escalating inferno!*

specials.name: Building fire
specials.description: Enemies take a penalty to saves against ongoing fire damage equal to the escalation die.

specials.name: Igneous aura
specials.description: Ranged weapon attacks with non-magical weapons or non-magical ammunition against the salamander fail—the missiles simply burn up mid-air.

specials.name: Heat metal
specials.description: Enemies who make a melee attack with a non-magical weapon against a salamander and who roll a natural 1 or 3 take ongoing fire damage equal to twice the salamander’s level unless they drop their weapon as a free action.

attacks.name: C: Ten-foot collapsing staff

attacks.name: C: Ten-foot collapsing staff (2 targets)
attacks.hit: 60 damage, and if there is a pit or ledge next to the target it must save or be pushed off and potentially take falling damage

attacks.hit: 25 psychic damage, and if it is the first time this battle this target is hit it becomes confused until the end of its next turn

extras.name: Aftereffect
extras.description: When the target is no longer confused it takes 50 psychic damage.

traits.name: Shadowy step
traits.description: When the escalation die advances the rakshasa teleports as a free action to any spot it can see nearby or faraway. If the rakshasa is engaged with a PC, that character’s player can choose to prevent the teleportation at the cost of the escalation die not advancing.

traits.name: Shadow pounce
traits.description: Once per round as a free action when an enemy moves into engagement with the rakshasa it can roll a save (11+), on a success the rakshasa teleports into engagement with the enemy with the fewest hit points.

traits.name: Shapechange
traits.description: As a standard action, the rakshasa can change its form to that of any humanoid, or back to its own shape. Seeing through the shapechange requires a DC 20 skill check.

specials.name: Allies
specials.description: The rakshasa isn’t alone—it bought a team of hirelings and hangers-on into the dungeon with it, though they are currently elsewhere. When the escalation die reaches 3+ these allies rush into the fight and act at the start of the round.

specials.name: Lockheart
specials.description:
The first time a rakshasa is dropped to 0 hit points, it dies but will definitely be reborn, even if the PCs attempt to use an icon die result to prevent the resurrection. A PC who scores a critical hit against the rakshasa can attempt to nullify lockheart by choosing to ignore all other effects of the critical hit (all damage, not just the doubling) and attempting a normal save. If the save succeeds, lockheart is ignored this battle. If the save fails, lockheart is still in effect. A rakshasa can only use lockheart once in its lifetime.

Alternatively, instead of rolling saves, the PCs could go on a quest to find the lockheart’s key before confronting the rakshasa! That’s a story angle you get to manipulate as you choose.

specials.name: Backwards palms
specials.description: When staggered, the rakshasa’s hands shapeshift so that its palms trade places with the backs of its hands. It not only looks extremely weird, it also presents the player characters with an odd choice: The next time the escalation die would advance, the PCs have to choose whether the escalation die will decrease by 1 (minimum 0) or whether this rakshasa gets to use the escalation die until the end of the battle. If the PC group is split, the decision goes to the character with the highest initiative.

traits.name: Shapechange
traits.description: As a standard action, the rakshasa can change its form to that of any humanoid, or back to its own shape. Seeing through the shapechange requires a DC 20 skill check.

specials.name: Contrabando
specials.description: The rakshasa has a stash of illicit substances—once per battle as a quick action, it can either deal 20 ongoing poison damage to one enemy that it has just left engagement with OR become dazed but heal 30 hit points at the end of each of its turns (save ends).

specials.name: Shapechanger’s surprise
specials.description: Once per battle as a quick action the rakshasa changes forms to something that causes consternation and misunderstanding among its enemies—causing each enemy to become dazed until the enemy with the lowest MD saves.

specials.name: Lockheart
specials.description:
The first time a rakshasa is dropped to 0 hit points, it dies but will definitely be reborn, even if the PCs attempt to use an icon die result to prevent the resurrection. A PC who scores a critical hit against the rakshasa can attempt to nullify lockheart by choosing to ignore all other effects of the critical hit (all damage, not just the doubling) and attempting a normal save. If the save succeeds, lockheart is ignored this battle. If the save fails, lockheart is still in effect. A rakshasa can only use lockheart once in its lifetime.

Alternatively, instead of rolling saves, the PCs could go on a quest to find the lockheart’s key before confronting the rakshasa! That’s a story angle you get to manipulate as you choose.

specials.name: Backwards palms
specials.description: When staggered, the rakshasa’s hands shapeshift so that its palms trade places with the backs of its hands. It not only looks extremely weird, it also presents the player characters with an odd choice: The next time the escalation die would advance, the PCs have to choose whether the escalation die will decrease by 1 (minimum 0) or whether this rakshasa gets to use the escalation die until the end of the battle. If the PC group is split, the decision goes to the character with the highest initiative.

traits.name: Unstoppable pounce
traits.description: The first time an enemy tries to intercept the devourer of wizards each round, the devourer of wizards can roll a single rending claws attack against the would-be interceptor. If the attack hits, the interception is ignored and the devourer of wizards can continue moving to its target unimpeded.

specials.name: Overwhelming distraction

traits.name: Blood-frenzy escalator
traits.description: While at least one creature in the battle is staggered or unconscious, the bulette gains a bonus to its attacks and damage equal to the escalation die. Creatures that have no blood (constructs, oozes, plant creatures, etc.) don’t trigger this ability.

traits.name: Earth surge
traits.description: Whenever the bumoorah takes damage from an attack, it rolls a save; on a 16+ it can immediately dive beneath the ground, preventing further attacks against it until it surfaces at the start of its next turn. Force attacks and opportunity attacks don’t trigger this ability.

traits.name: Serious burrower
traits.description: The bumoorah can burrow incredibly quickly for short distances. Bumoorahs are renowned for the dust-spurts and vibrating sound they generate as they shoot through the ground like hungry spears.

attacks.name: Latching bite
attacks.hit: or one enemy making saving throw rolls);6 damage

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: Add another ravenous cannibal mook to the mob (it must have been hiding somewhere nearby, or wasn’t really dead when it dropped earlier in the battle).

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: Increase the damage by +1 for each razor shark mook that has dropped this battle.

extras.name: Natural even miss

traits.name: Frenzy (group)
traits.description: When two or more razor sharks in the same mob are dropped to 0 hp by an attack, as a free action each dropped razor shark attacks one random nearby non-razor shark creature before it dies. That creature takes 1d8 damage.

traits.name: Water breather
traits.description: Sharks breathe underwater and swim very well. They’re not so good out of sea water (even if they jump), so treat them as semi-hazardous terrain while they’re busy thrashing to death outside the water.

extras.name: Natural 20
extras.description: This really angry kobold transforms into an undamaged red haze berserker after the attack.

traits.name: Weakling
traits.description: When building battles using this monster, it only counts as half a normal monster.

specials.name: Red rage
specials.description: Roll 2d20 for each of the kobold’s attacks and use the higher result.

extras.name: Both attacks hit the same target
extras.description: Until the end of its next turn, the target is affected by the reaver’s *fear aura* even if it has more than 36 hp.

traits.name: Phasing
traits.description:
While the escalation die is odd, the reaver takes no damage and suffers no effects from attacks with natural attack rolls less than 18+ (or 16+ for attacks that deal holy damage). It does take full damage and effects from attacks that are able to affect it.

While phasing, the reaver can move but creatures can’t intercept it, and it can travel through solid objects but not endits turn in them. In addition, while phasing the reaver can’t attack (including opportunity attacks) or affect the physical world except in the following way: When an enemy starts its turn engaged with the phased reaver, it takes 13 negative energy damage.

The reaver can also use phasing outside of battle, but only for a short time.

traits.name: Call upon death shades
traits.description: Until the reaver drops to 0 hp, when one of its living (not undead or construct) enemies or non-mook allies rolls a death save or dies, a death shade enters the battle. Death shades act immediately after the reaver in initiative order.

traits.name: Fear aura
traits.description: While engaged with this creature, enemies with 36 hp or fewer are dazed and do not add the escalation die to their attacks.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: Reavers ignore the bonds of gravity while they’re phasing.

extras.name: Natural even hit or miss
extras.description: Deal 2d6 bonus damage to the target

attacks.name: Stompy iron boots
attacks.attack: +8 vs. PD (1 staggered or unconscious enemy)

traits.name: Ridey-horsey
traits.description: While the target is taking ongoing damage from this attack, the redcap is riding the target’s shoulders with its knives in the target’s ears, and once during its turn the redcap can use a move action to make the target move anywhere nearby that won’t directly cause it harm (but opportunity attacks are fair game).

traits.name: Impossible teleport
traits.description: When the redcap scores a critical hit OR when a PC or a player at the table says the bad word, the redcap can teleport to a nearby hidden location it can see as a free action.

traits.name: Pop-out surprise
traits.description: When the redcap starts its turn and no enemy can see it, it can make a pop-out and ride ‘em attack that turn as a standard action

extras.name: Natural even hit or miss

attacks.name: C: Burning breath

traits.name: Red rage
traits.description: When the escalation die is odd, the fiery vanquisher can roll two d20s for its heavy axe attack and use the best result.

traits.name: Resist fire 14+
traits.description: When a fire attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 14+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

specials.name: Limited flight
specials.description: At the start of each turn, roll a /r d6. If the result is less than or equal to the escalation die, the dragonic gains flight as a move action during its turns thanks to a pair of wings it unfurls from its back. The flight tends to be more power-flapping or gliding from one place to another rather than hovering. Flamewings who also have limited flight prefer to use their burning wings to fly in combat wherever possible, resorting to their physical wings only if needed.

specials.name: Blood of the wyrm
specials.description: This dragonic displays traits of its forebears, the mighty wyrms. Roll a /r d10 and consult the random dragon ability table, or choose one of the first ten options that looks likely to shape the story or battle.

attacks.name: Burning mace
attacks.hit: 45 damage and 45 fire damage, divided between the targets if two different enemies are hit, or piled onto one target if only one target is hit.

attacks.name: R: Fireball breath (big)
attacks.attack: +17 vs. AC (2d3 nearby or faraway enemies in a group)

traits.name: Attack on the wing
traits.description: The flamewing can make attacks mid-movement as it flies past without taking opportunity attacks, but at a –2 attack penalty. It can split its burning mace attack between two enemies in two locations as it flies past. As its wings are made of fire, the flamewing might accidentally set the environment ablaze, which might benefit one side or the other in the battle (or harm both).

traits.name: Fiery temper
traits.description: When the flamewing is forced to land, it rolls 3d20 for its next attack roll and takes the best result.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: The flamewing can fly, and fly fast—soaring on wings of flame. However, its turning circle isn’t great and it can’t hover, so in tight quarters it needs to land. Also, its wings are made of fire, and overusing its fireball breath can cause the wings to gutter and fade.

traits.name: Resist fire 16+
traits.description: When a fire attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 16+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

specials.name: Healed by fire
specials.description: The first time each battle the flamewing is hit by a fire attack, instead of taking the fire damage it heals that many hit points.

specials.name: Tail whip
specials.description: The dragonic deals 2d12 extra damage to a target it misses with a melee attack.

traits.name: Furnace aura
traits.description: When a creature is engaged with the remorhaz (or grabbed by it) at the start of its turn, it takes fire damage equal to 10 x the escalation die.

traits.name: Sluggish initiative
traits.description: The queen may be sluggish after eating unsuccessful suitors, laying eggs, or moving across the ice like a rushing avalanche. Roll 2d10 to determine her current initiative.

specials.name: Bejeweled remorhaz
specials.description: The remorhaz has glowing “jewels” on its armored plates. When a nearby or far away enemy misses with an attack against the remorhaz, that enemy chooses one: It takes 25 fire damage; OR one piece of its non-magical equipment (something useful, GM’s choice) melts or burns up. Adjust skill checks or stats accordingly

specials.name: Remorhaz steamer
specials.description: The remorhaz is melting the ice/snow all the time and obscuring steam rises into the air. Ranged attacks against the remorhaz take a –2 penalty, or a –4 penalty if the attacker is far away.

specials.name: Spiney remorhaz
specials.description: The remorhaz is covered in red-hot spines. When a nearby enemy rolls a natural 1–5 with an attack roll, it takes 30 fire damage unless it has somehow protected itself from the heat.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: The resurgent phoenix can fly as well or better than anything you’ve seen airborne.

traits.name: Flaming wings
traits.description: The resurgent phoenix deals 7 fire damage to each enemy that ends it turn engaged with the phoenix.

traits.name: Resist fire 16+
traits.description: When a fire attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 16+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

traits.name: Spectacular effects
traits.description: When the phoenix is dealt a critical hit, it must roll an easy save (6+). If the save fails, the phoenix drops to 0 hit points; see the reborn in fire ability below!

traits.name: Reborn in fire
traits.description:
Whenever the resurgent phoenix drops to 0 hit points, roll a /r d20 and add the escalation die. For each time this phoenix has rolled its reborn in fire ability earlier this battle, subtract 10 from the roll. For example, a phoenix making its second reborn in fire roll (because its first roll ended up being 20+!) when the escalation die is 6 would roll the d20 and subtract 4.

20+: The flamebird phoenix is immediately reborn, healing to 70 hit points, and keeps fighting!

15–19: The phoenix is reborn in fire, but vaults into the overworld, removed from the battle. On the other hand, it’s not done with the PCs! Add the phoenix to an upcoming battle by surprise, adding it as an additional monster not accounted for by the usual encounter-building calculations.

8–14: The flamebird phoenix is reborn in fire but wants nothing more to do with this battle. It makes a conflagration of rebirth attack, but when the attack is over it shoots off into the overworld so quickly that it’s a teleport effect, and does not return to the battle, nor to the adventure.

7 or less: The phoenix flares back to life somewhere nearby in a few hours, days, months, or years. Probably not relevant to the PCs unless they or the phoenix bear a special grudge.

The effect is cumulative (so the second time you heal, the third time, etc.) if you pay the devil’s due more than once before using a recovery.

traits.name: The river’s song
traits.description: When a creature is confused from the naiad’s watery words attack, it immediately moves into the water next to the naiad as a free action to defend the naiad. The target takes half the damage of the next attack that hits the naiad. During its turn, it doesn’t attack, instead moving to stay next to the naiad. Each time the target fails its save, it will again defend the naiad against the next attack that hits it, taking half damage.

traits.name: One with the river
traits.description: A naiad can walk on the surface of water, making it seem shallow, and it can swim through the water and breathe underwater with ease. Its enemies might have a more difficult time engaging it.

traits.name: Domain bound
traits.description: Nymphs are tied to an area of land or water. Land areas will be at most a couple miles wide; water areas might be much larger. As a rule, nymphs can’t leave the area they’re bound to.

traits.name: Limited immortality
traits.description: A nymph that drops to 0 hit points or is otherwise slain will eventually return to life in its domain, so long as its domain and its secret survives. After an hour, a nymph needs a hard save to return to life. After eight hours, a nymph needs a normal save to return to life. If the nymph has still not returned, roll an easy save at the end of each 24 hours until the nymph succeeds.

traits.name: Note on types
traits.description: Nymphs with the humanoid type probably remember themselves. Nymphs that have probably forgotten their original selves have the elemental type.

specials.name: Naiad’s cleansing
specials.description: Each time a target confused by watery words fails its save, it will forget something important. GM’s choice or player’s suggestion!

attacks.name: Enchanting touch

traits.name: Siren

traits.name: Rusalka
traits.description: Targets hit by the river-spirit’s enchanting touch attack must start rolling last gasp saves instead of being confused. On the fourth failure, they fall into a long sleep that mortals call a coma.

traits.name: Banshee
traits.description: The river-spirit’s otherworldly aria attack becomes haunting wail, deals negative energy damage, and on a natural 18+, the target is weakened (save ends).

traits.name: Power of a name

attacks.hit: The target must choose one: 60 damage and the target can be teleported into engagement with one of the royal bearer’s allies; OR the target loses a random magical implement, shield, or weapon to the glittering bearer

extras.description: No choice, the target suffers both effects.

traits.description: The glittering bearer normally hovers a foot or two off the ground, though it can achieve impressive elevation and mobility if need be.

traits.name: Lost opportunity

traits.name: Ghostly
traits.description: This creature has resist damage 16+ to all damage except force damage, which damages it normally. A glittering bearer can move through solid objects but it can’t end its movement inside them.

attacks.hit: 10 damage, and the target is now considered to be wearing no armor (the armor is damaged beyond repair; adjust defenses accordingly). traits.description: Whenever a creature hits the rust monster with a melee weapon, the attacker must roll a save; on a failure, the weapon is destroyed. Magic weapons require an easy save (6+) instead. This effect is permanent.

traits.name: Rust's targets
traits.description: Magic items wielded by creatures with 100 hp or more are not affected by the rust monster’s ability to destroy items (but the target still takes damage).

traits.name: Saving quirks
traits.description: Before rolling a save for a magic item, a PC can gain a +5 bonus to the save by agreeing to roleplay the item’s quirk as a huge element of their personality until the next full heal-up. specials.name: Tail whirligig
specials.description: When an enemy targets the rust monster obliterator with a spell, the rust monster rolls a save. On a success, the spell has no effect on the rust monster. If the rust monster is staggered, it must roll a hard save (16+) instead.
