specials.name: Big antenna
specials.description: When the rust monster scores a critical hit, it can try to destroy another random magic item in the target’s possession (or a random normal item if the target has no other magic items). The creature must roll a save for the item, as usual.

extras.name: Natural 2-5
extras.description: Target is hampered (save ends).

traits.name: Contagious ennui
traits.description: Each enemy that misses an attack with a natural odd roll this battle takes a -2 penalty to all its defenses until they score a critical hit or the sadsack is reduced to 0 hit points. (As usual, this ability does not stack.)

traits.name: Ghostly
traits.description: This creature has resist damage 12+ to all damage except holy damage. A ghost can move through solid objects, but can’t end its turn inside them.

traits.name: Relic affinity
traits.description: Sadsacks are also vulnerable to the type of weapon or attack that ended their lives. Interpret this liberally, GM.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: Gravity does not influence sadsacks unless they are staggered. When they’re staggered, they sink to the ground and stay there.

traits.name: Bound hauntings
traits.description:
Most ghosts are bound to an area, usually the area of their death. This ability won’t come up much in play, but it does make it seem likely that ghosts can be easier to get away from than other monsters. Move far enough fast enough and the ghost returns to the area it’s bound to. Occasionally festivals for the dead or other rituals can call bound ghosts from their hauntings, but those are unusual and temporary circumstances.

Exceptions: There may be ghosts that are bound to people, or events, or phenomena that travel. There might even be ghosts that aren’t bound to anything, but at that stage there are several other questions that surface and odd magical, iconic, or unique intervention seems likely.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description:
Most ghosts fly, though some may be quite slow, seeming to drift or walking on air. Ghosts that fly in unusual ways will be flagged with their own abilities.

Exceptions: Not all ghosts fly. Some seem constrained to act much like they acted when they were alive, and flying wasn’t part of their life package.

traits.name: Unnatural touch
traits.description:
Many ghosts can alter the temperature of their environment to more closely match the underworld or afterlife that they’ve so far evaded. Sometimes that’s icy cold, sometimes that’s burning hot, and sometimes it’s just kind of normal, which would go unnoticed unless the ghost is somewhere abnormal!

Exceptions: This is more of a special effect of ghost stories than part of a creature’s combat abilities, and you can safely ignore it unless you find telling moments when it adds to the game.

extras.name: Natural even hit or miss
extras.description: The priest teleports the target next to one of its nearby allies that it can see, who engages it as a free action. It can’t teleport the target to a location that causes it direct damage (so into a pool of flaming oil is out, but off a ship into the sea is fine).

attacks.name: R: Glowpriest’s prayer
attacks.hit: 12 psychic damage, and if the attack hits 2 or more targets, roll 1d8 after the attack for the prayer’s effect

traits.name: 1-2 (Hymn of hate)
traits.description: One random nearby conscious enemy takes 4d6 negative energy damage.

traits.name: 3-4 (Curse of despair)
traits.description: Each target that was hit takes a -2 penalty (non-cumulative) to all saves until the end of the battle.

traits.name: 5-6 (Scream of victory)
traits.description: Until the start of the glowpriest’s next turn, each sahuagin and demon in the battle adds the escalation die to its attacks and the PCs don’t.

traits.name: 7-8 (Word of refuge)
traits.description: Remove the glowpriest from play. At the start of its next turn, return it to play nearby its original location. It gains a +4 bonus to all defenses until the end of its next turn after it returns to play.

traits.name: Water breather
traits.description: Sahuagin breathe underwater and swim very well.

extras.name: Natural 4, 8, 12, 16, 20
extras.description: The target takes 10 ongoing damage.

attacks.name: R: Heavy crossbow
attacks.attack: +10 vs. AC (1 nearby or far away enemy)

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The target takes 10 ongoing damage.

traits.name: Limited escalator
traits.description: The sahuagin mutant adds the escalation die to its attacks until the die is 5+.

traits.name: Water breather
traits.description: Sahuagin breathe underwater and swim very well.

specials.name: Punisher
specials.description: When an enemy intercepts the sahuagin mutant, it takes 4d8 damage from the mutant’s claws and teeth.

specials.name: Ripper
specials.description: When an enemy makes a melee attack against the sahuagin mutant and rolls a natural odd miss, that enemy takes 2d8 damage.

extras.name: Natural even hit against a *stuck* or *hampered* enemy
extras.description: The target takes 1d6 extra damage.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The target is hampered (save ends).

extras.name: Natural odd hit
extras.description: The target is stuck (save ends).

traits.name: Blood rage
traits.description: The sahuagin raider gains a +2 attack bonus while it’s staggered.

traits.name: Water breather
traits.description: Sahuagin breathe underwater and swim very well.

extras.name: Natural 20
extras.description: Increase the escalation die by 1, and the target is hampered (makes only basic attacks) until the end of its next turn.

attacks.name: R: Barbed crossbow
attacks.attack: +9 vs. AC (1 nearby enemy or a far away enemy at -2 atk);

traits.name: Blood frenzy
traits.description: Make a note of the escalation die when the sahuagin becomes staggered. The sahuagin gains a bonus to its melee attacks and damage equal to the escalation die value for the rest of the battle.

traits.name: Water breather
traits.description: Sahuagin breathe underwater and swim very well.

specials.name: Demon-touched
specials.description: Roll a d6 on the demon abilities table. The sahuagin gains that ability.

extras.name: Natural 1-3
extras.description: The screaming hoardling drops its weapon and makes a *howl of emptiness* attack as a free action.

extras.name: Natural 1-3
extras.description: The screaming hoardling drops its weapon and makes a *howl of emptiness* attack

extras.name: Effect
extras.description: The screaming hoardling is dazed and vulnerable until the start of its next turn as it scrambles for its ‘lost treasure’, the weapon it just dropped.

traits.name: Piecemeal armor
traits.description: When the screaming hoardling survives a critical hit to AC it makes a howl of emptiness attack as a free action, as a piece of its scavenged armor falls away. Knock a point off its AC.

specials.name: Eternal greed
specials.description: If the screaming hoardling is reduced to zero HP while coping with the effects of its howl of emptiness attack, at the start of the next turn it rises with 36 HP, then spends a quick action (or two) to re-equip lost items. A character can negate this recovery-from-death by returning a lost item to the corpse with a quick action. If a character has for some reason taken the screaming hoardling’s fallen treasure, they will find themselves pursued by an unkillable enemy until they give that item back.

attacks.name: C: Treacherous scream
attacks.attack: +11 vs. MD (up to 2 nearby or far away enemies)
attacks.hit: 6 psychic damage, and the target takes 2d6 psychic damage the first time it succeeds at a save before the end of its next turn.

traits.name: Limited flight
traits.description: The haunted skull can glide and hover, always within seven or eight feet of the ground.

traits.name: Lost opportunity
traits.description: This creature can’t make opportunity attacks.

attacks.name: Strangling tentacles
attacks.hit: 5 damage, and 5 ongoing damage (damage also ends if the target is no longer engaged with the star-mask)

attacks.name: C: Suffocating thoughts
attacks.hit: Until the end of the battle, if the target drops to 0 hp or below, it rejoins the fight as a 5th level star-mask cultist. Converted player character star-mask cultists can be freed from their masks as a standard action by a character next to them. Use cultist stats and ignore the PC’s hit points and normal attacks and powers; some hand waving may be necessary here, be forgiving if the PCs spend serious resources to deal with the problem during combat.

traits.name: Group ability
traits.description: For every four star-masks in the battle (round up), one of them can use suffocating thoughts once during the battle.

traits.name: Leap
traits.description: When the escalation die is odd, the star-mask can move and engage a nearby enemy as a quick action.

attacks.name: C: Rippling words
attacks.hit: The target falls unconscious as it begins to slumber (save ends; an ally next to the target can also use a standard action to wake the target)

extras.name: Limited use
extras.description: When the escalation die is odd.

traits.name: Call of the sea
traits.description: Twice per battle as a quick action (once per round), the nereid can call to a slumbering creature, and during its next turn (while still unconscious), that creature will swim under the water seeking the nereid. The creature must start making last gasp saves, which replace its save against being unconscious. After the fourth failure, it drowns.

traits.name: Child of the sea
traits.description: The nereid can walk atop the waves and move (and breathe) underwater without restraint. Its enemies might have a more difficult time engaging it.

traits.name: Domain bound
traits.description: Nymphs are tied to an area of land or water. Land areas will be at most a couple miles wide; water areas might be much larger. As a rule, nymphs can’t leave the area they’re bound to.

traits.name: Limited immortality
traits.description: A nymph that drops to 0 hit points or is otherwise slain will eventually return to life in its domain, so long as its domain and its secret survives. After an hour, a nymph needs a hard save to return to life. After eight hours, a nymph needs a normal save to return to life. If the nymph has still not returned, roll an easy save at the end of each 24 hours until the nymph succeeds.

traits.name: Note on types
traits.description: Nymphs with the humanoid type probably remember themselves. Nymphs that have probably forgotten their original selves have the elemental type.

traits.name: Frenzy
traits.description: While staggered, if the iron sea shark is unengaged at the start of its turn, it must roll an easy save (6+). On a failure, the shark must move and attack a random nearby enemy that’s staggered, or a random nearby if there are no staggered enemies.

traits.name: Shredder
traits.description: When an enemy misses with a melee attack against an iron sea shark and rolls a natural 1-5, the attacker takes 2d6 damage.

traits.name: Water breather
traits.description: Sharks breathe underwater and swim very well. They’re not so good out of sea water (even if they jump), so treat them as semi-hazardous terrain while they’re busy thrashing to death outside the water.

extras.name: Natural even hit or miss
extras.description: The hydra’s next gnashing teeth attack, if it has an attack left this turn, can be against any nearby enemy instead of against a creature engaged with it.

traits.name: Let’s not waste space
traits.description: The seven-headed hydra has all the same abilities as the five-headed hydra, except that the heads that get sprouted are the 8th and 9th and those heads/attacks come with 50 new hit points apiece.

traits.name: Resist opportunity attacks 16+
traits.description: When an opportunity attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 16+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

specials.name: Pyrohydra
specials.description: When the hydra gets a natural even attack roll with a gnashing teeth attack, its next attack that turn (if it has one) is a flame breath attack instead. Note that flame breath attacks don’t lead to other flaming breaths; the hydra has to return to making a gnashing teeth attack first.

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The target is confused (hard save ends, 16+).

attacks.name: C: Nightmare breath
attacks.attack: +12 vs. MD (1d3 nearby or far away enemies)
attacks.hit: 60 negative energy damage, and the target becomes a living shadow (hard save ends, 16+)

traits.name: Living shadow
traits.description: While a living shadow, the target can’t physically interact with or gain aid from companions or aid them (including healing, bonuses, and effects) but is otherwise “normal.”

traits.name: Made of shadow
traits.description: The shadow dragon perceives the invisible, is unaffected by the blur spell, and ignores illusions. Rogues attempting to shadow walk near a shadow dragon end up in the dragon’s belly (save ends). While there, they are helpless and take 2d12 damage at the start of each of their turns until they save and fall back out of shadow.

traits.name: Shadowy escalation
traits.description: When in poorly lit areas of shadow, the dragon adds the escalation die to its attack rolls. Complete darkness or bright daylight negates the ability.

traits.name: On Holy Ground
traits.description: While on “holy ground” such as a temple or consecrated shrine, all hard saves against shadow dragon effects become normal saves. As a standard action, a cleric who invokes the gods can produce a similar anti-shadow effect in the nearby area until the start of their next turn, or they can turn hard saves against shadow dragon abilities to easy saves if that area is already on holy ground. Shadow dragons try to avoid holy ground, and shadow thieves can only enter it while possessing victims and will flee once the possession ends. It’s up to the GM what counts as “holy ground” in their game.

specials.name: Shadow illusions
specials.description: As a standard action, the dragon can appear to be humanoid, usually disguising itself as an unthreatening old man in a cloak (DC 35 to detect). Daylight will show the illusion for what it is—an insubstantial dragon. Dragons with a Book of Many Faces will have perfect humanoid disguises. Dropping the illusion is a free action.

specials.name: Shadowy phasing
specials.description: When the escalation die is even, natural odd attack rolls against the dragon automatically miss. When the escalation die is odd, natural even attack rolls against the dragon automatically miss. Attacks that deal holy damage ignore this ability.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: After the current battle is over, the next time this day that the target takes ongoing damage, the shadow mongoose gets to make a *destruction of fate* attack against the target.

attacks.name: R: Destruction of fate
attacks.attack: +9 vs. MD (one target that has been hit twice by the shadow mongoose this battle)
attacks.hit: The target rolls their icon dice, and any that come up 1-4 the shadow mongoose steals until the end of the day. At the start of the next day the target rolls a save (11+) for each stolen icon relationship, on a success the icon relationship die returns to them.

extras.name: Crit
extras.description: …and the shadow mongoose steals an item belonging to the target, preferably a magic one but sometimes the most vital one (a key, a map).

traits.name: Shadow’s slide
traits.description: The shadow mongoose can move over any solid surface, slithering like a shadow.

traits.name: Play dead
traits.description: Once per battle the shadow mongoose may fake being dead. Only magical senses and a DC 25 skill roll from the PC who struck the ‘killing blow’ will detect that the creature is still alive. Shadow mongooses like to fake their deaths so that they can escape battle with their stolen icon relationships. Since shadow anatomy isn’t entirely biological, this ability functions like fleeing the battle if it succeeds, the PCs can go ahead and blast away at what they think is the corpse, but they’ll be fragging the mongoose’s shadows, not the mongoose itself.

traits.name: Trapper
traits.description: The shadow mongoose can change shape, though not mid-battle. Shadow mongoose destroyers of fate use this ability to seem innocuous until they are ready to strike.

traits.name: Shadow fate
traits.description: When the shadow mongoose dies all the icon relationship dice that it stole return to their owners. The person who killed the shadow mongoose gains a magic item that the shadow mongoose had stolen (though maybe not one that it had stolen from the party).

specials.name: Drop the loot
specials.description: The shadow mongoose flees the battle. One nearby enemy of the shadow mongoose has their icon relationships flip positive to negative and vise-versa (conflicted relationships are unaffected). This relationship inversion is temporary, lasting only until the end of the next game session.

specials.name: Shadow dancer
specials.description: If the shadow mongoose doesn’t attack on its turn it can turn into a flat shadow, and cannot be intercepted or attacked it is moving in this form. When it returns to its normal form, it deals double damage with its next attack, hit or miss.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: d12 damage to a nearby target not engaged with the shadow mongoose.

attacks.name: Subversion of fate
attacks.attack: +11 vs. MD (one target that has been hit twice by the shadow mongoose this battle)
attacks.hit: The shadow mongoose steals the escalation die until the end of its next turn. While the escalation die is stolen, all shadow mongooses and their allies use it, and the adventurers do not.

extras.name: Crit
extras.description: …and the shadow mongoose steals an aspect belonging to the target. The target might lose their age, or lose part of their appearance, or an outward personality quirk. The character’s race, class, attributes etc. remain intact, as does their core personality and their memories.

extras.name: Quick use
extras.description: 1/round, as a quick action.

traits.name: Shadow’s flight
traits.description: The shadow mongoose may become a thing of dark smoke and shadow, flying swiftly through the air or through the smallest cracks.

traits.name: Play dead
traits.description: Once per battle the shadow mongoose may fake being dead. Only magical senses and a DC 30 skill roll from the PC who struck the ‘killing blow’ will detect that the creature is still alive. Shadow mongooses like to fake their deaths so that they can escape battle with their stolen icon relationships. Since shadow anatomy isn’t entirely biological, this ability functions like fleeing the battle if it succeeds, the PCs can go ahead and blast away at what they think is the corpse, but they’ll be fragging the mongoose’s shadows, not the mongoose itself.

traits.name: Trader
traits.description: The shadow mongoose can change shape, though not mid-battle. Shadow mongoose subverters sometimes take on non-shadowy visages so that they can set up shop as traders, offering to take aspects that others do not want, or selling stolen or traded aspects to those that do desire them.

traits.name: Shadow fate
traits.description: When the shadow mongoose dies all the aspects that it stole return to their owners. Stolen aspects that have been traded away also return, but slowly. The person who killed the shadow mongoose gains a random aspect chosen by the GM.

specials.name: Drop the loot
specials.description: The shadow mongoose flees the battle. One nearby enemy of the shadow mongoose gains an unwanted aspect. This new unwanted aspect is temporary, lasting only until the end of the next game session.

specials.name: Shadow dancer
specials.description: If the shadow mongoose doesn’t attack on its turn it can turn into a flat shadow, and cannot be intercepted or attacked it is moving in this form. When it returns to its normal form, it deals double damage with its next attack, hit or miss.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: Make a second *tenebrous claws* attack as a free action.

attacks.name: Theft of fate
attacks.attack: +13 vs. MD (one target that has been hit twice by the shadow mongoose this battle)
attacks.hit: The shadow mongoose steals an icon die from the target. The target may not use the stolen icon die, until the shadow mongoose gives it back, or the shadow mongoose dies.

extras.name: Crit
extras.description: …and the relationship that the adventurer has with that icon flips from positive to negative or negative to positive. Conflicted relationships are unaffected.

extras.name: Quick use
extras.description: 1/round, as a quick action.

traits.name: Shadow speed
traits.description: As a move action the shadow mongoose may teleport into engagement with a target that it missed the previous round.

traits.name: Play dead
traits.description: Once per battle the shadow mongoose may fake being dead. Only magical senses and a DC 35 skill roll from the PC who struck the ‘killing blow’ will detect that the creature is still alive. Shadow mongooses like to fake their deaths so that they can escape battle with their stolen icon relationships. Since shadow anatomy isn’t entirely biological, this ability functions like fleeing the battle if it succeeds, the PCs can go ahead and blast away at what they think is the corpse, but they’ll be fragging the mongoose’s shadows, not the mongoose itself.

traits.name: Trickster
traits.description: The shadow mongoose can change shape, though not mid-battle. Shadow mongooses sometimes join adventuring parties as helpful hirelings, love interests, or local guides to repeatedly steal icon relationships from adventurers.

traits.name: Shadow fate
traits.description: When the shadow mongoose dies all the icon relationship dice that it stole return to their owners. The person who killed the shadow mongoose gains 1d3 ‘5’ icon dice results with a random icon that they do not have a relationship with OR a 6 with the Trickster Icon if they do not have a relationship with him (roll /r 1d3 for relationship type: 1=Negative, 2= Conflicted, 3= Positive).

specials.name: Drop the loot
specials.description: The shadow mongoose flees the battle. One nearby enemy of the shadow mongoose gains an unwanted icon relationship worth 1d3 icon dice. This new relationship is temporary, lasting only until the end of the next game session.

specials.name: Shadow dancer
specials.description: If the shadow mongoose doesn’t attack on its turn it can turn into a flat shadow, and cannot be intercepted or attacked it is moving in this form. When it returns to its normal form, it deals double damage with its next attack, hit or miss.

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The target takes 20 negative energy damage, and the shadow thief can make a shadow possession attack as a free action (but see group ability).

attacks.name: C: Shadow possession
attacks.attack: +13 vs. MD (1 enemy hit by shadow strangulation)
attacks.hit: The shadow thief “crawls inside” the target. The target is confused (save ends), and the shadow thief can’t be the target of an attack or effect until it’s forced from the target’s body when that creature saves against the confusion effect.

traits.name: Group ability
traits.description: For every four shadow thieves in the battle (round up), one of them can use shadow possession during the battle.

traits.name: Shadow thievery
traits.description: The shadow thief is an extension of the shadow dragon, not really a separate entity. When it drops to 0 hp, it flees back to the shadow dragon and merges with it. When this happens, if there is at least one enemy engaged with that shadow thief, the thief chooses one enemy engaged with it. Roll a ; on a 16+, the shadow thief steals a random magic item from the chosen enemy as it flees back to the dragon (but see stop…thief below). Stolen items are replaced with shadowy duplicates that work until the end of the battle then fade to nothingness. The items can be recovered if the dragon is slain in the same battle.

traits.name: Stop…thief! When a shadow thief steals an item, the creature it steals from can choose to prevent the theft, but at a cost. If the natural d20 thievery roll was odd, the target of the thievery attempt can choose to keep the item but become *hampered* (save ends) as they wrestle with the shadow. If the natural thievery roll was even, the target has the same choice, but it’s a hard save (16+) to end the hampered effect.
traits.description: Stop…thief! When a shadow thief steals an item, the creature it steals from can choose to prevent the theft, but at a cost. If the natural  thievery roll was odd, the target of the thievery attempt can choose to keep the item but become hampered (save ends) as they wrestle with the shadow. If the natural thievery roll was even, the target has the same choice, but it’s a hard save (16+) to end the hampered effect.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The hound leaves teeth in the wound; the target takes 5 ongoing damage, and the hound takes 1d6 damage.

traits.name: Chomp chomp chomp
traits.description: Enemies with a lower initiative than the hound take a –5 penalty to disengage checks against it.

traits.name: skilled intercept 11+
traits.description: Once per round, an engaged skeletal hound can attempt to pop free and intercept an enemy moving past it. Roll a normal save; on 11+, it succeeds.

traits.name: Stay whole
traits.description: At the start of its turn, a skin devil heals 8 hp. If it doesn’t heal up to its maximum hit points, it loses its ability to heal from this ability until the end of the battle.

traits.name: Structural collapse
traits.description: While the skin devil is staggered, when an enemy damages it, it loses an additional 4 hp as the hapless thing fails to hold its boneless, bulky mass together.

traits.name: Weakling
traits.description: When building battles using this monster, it only counts as half a normal monster.

traits.name: Free-form covert ability—Unnoticed
traits.description: The skin devil is routinely able to pass through civilized areas without alerting dogs, bouncers, city guards, or passersby. If the thing attacks, that’s when you notice that it’s not a human but a monstrous pile of flesh. In addition to passing unnoticed in crowds, it uses its fluid shape to sneak through hidden places, and it doesn’t make much noise unless it wants to. PCs looking for the devil won’t find it unless they have some special information or advantage, and even then it’s a hard check (DC 25). Normally when PCs think they have the devil cornered, it escapes through a tight exit that it had previously identified.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The skull crab has burrowed its tentacles into the target’s flesh; the target takes a –1 penalty to all d20 rolls (save ends). Until the target saves, whenever it moves the skull crab comes with it, and the crab will continue to bite the target.

extras.name: Each failed save
extras.description: The penalty to all d20 rolls increases by –1 (first failed save = –2 penalty, etc.)

traits.name: Meat puppet
traits.description: If a creature fails three consecutive saves against the scrabbling tentacles effect, attacks against the skull crab deal half damage to it and half to that creature as the crab burrows deep. The effect lasts until the creature saves.

traits.name: Sudden leap
traits.description: Once per battle as a move action, the skull crab can engage a nearby or far away enemy.

specials.name: New host
specials.description: When an enemy making saves against the scrambling tentacles effect drops to 0 hp or below, the skull crab eggs rush out of its skull and the crab dies. That enemy must start making last gasp saves in addition to any death saves, with it turning into a xombie on the fourth failure.

extras.name: Natural odd hit
extras.description: The target is stuck (save ends) from looking into the void within it.

traits.name: Fear
traits.description: While engaged with this creature, enemies that have 60 hp or fewer are dazed (-4 attack) and do not add the escalation die to their attacks.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: Deal 25 damage to the slaughter pit shade; then add a 3rd level battle shade OR a 3rd level archer shade to the battle that will act 1d6 initiative counts after the slaughter pit shade acted. Treat this battle or archer shade as if it had used its *earthen assault* ability, so that it starts off the table and reappears where it likes nearby the slaughter pit shade.

traits.name: All are one
traits.description: When a nearby non-mook undead ally drops to 0 hit points, the slaughter pit shade immediately removes one ongoing condition.

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The target takes 3 extra acid damage and is stuck (hard save ends, 16+).

traits.name: Acidic
traits.description: When a creature is engaged with the slime-skull or stuck from its grasping slime tendrils attack at the start of its turn, it takes 3 acid damage.

traits.name: Slimy blastback
traits.description: When an enemy engaged with the slime-skull hits it with a melee attack, the slime-skull fires a blast of acidic slime back at that creature, which takes 1d4 acid damage.

traits.name: Slow
traits.description: This creature is slow. It only moves when the escalation die is odd or 6+.

traits.name: Wall-crawler
traits.description: A slime-skull can climb on ceilings and walls as easily as it moves on the ground.

specials.name: Breeder
specials.description: If the slime-skull kills a creature, it takes that creature’s head as a standard action and attempts to escape (it can squeeze through gaps as small as the skull). The slain creature can’t be resurrected until its skull is recovered because its spirit is now trapped within the skull. If the PCs don’t track down the slime-skull before their next full heal-up (or within a day), the stolen skull will transform into another slime-skull. Attempts to resurrect the creature become much more difficult, perhaps even impossible, at that point.

attacks.name: C: Swirling winds
attacks.attack: +8 vs. PD (1d3 random conscious nearby enemies)

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The target pops free from the elemental.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: It’s quick and lively.

traits.name: Resist non-spell damage 16+
traits.description: When a non-spell attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 16+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

traits.name: Repair damage 10 and below
traits.description: When the earth elemental is targeted by a natural attack roll of 10 or less, the elemental heals 1d6 damage before taking any damage from the attack.

specials.name: Burrow
specials.description: Not all earth elementals burrow, though if yours is particularly nasty or associated with a particular icon, it can.

attacks.name: Whipping flames
attacks.hit: 8 fire damage, and 4 ongoing fire damage to a random nearby enemy (including an unconscious one)

traits.name: Melee burn
traits.description: When an enemy makes a natural odd melee attack roll against the fire elemental, that attacker takes 1d8 fire damage.

traits.name: Resist fire 18+
traits.description: When a fire attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 18+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

traits.name: Liquid empowerment
traits.description: The water elemental gains a +2 bonus to attacks and all defenses while it’s in contact with a body of water, or while it’s nearby a sizeable body of water. A bucket or a bathtub of liquid doesn’t count; it must be at least a pond, creek, or maybe a large fountain. If the water elemental moves far away from the body of water the empowerment ends.

traits.name: Resist weapon damage 16+
traits.description: When a weapon attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 16+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

extras.name: Full embrace
extras.description: If the target is the only creature engaged with the smoke devil, the attack deals 30 poison damage instead.

attacks.name: Ember Burst
attacks.attack: +10 vs PD (each enemy engaged with the devil)
attacks.hit: The target takes 5 fire damage for each creature hit by the smoke devil earlier in the battle (max 15 damage; remember to track this)

traits.name: Ember of hate
traits.description: Each time the smoke devil hits an enemy, the embers floating in the center of its body glow more brightly. Once per battle as a free action during its turn, the devil can make an ember burst attack. It also makes this attack as an interrupt action when it drops to 0 hp.

traits.name: Devil's Due (Formless)
traits.description: When you choose to add the escalation die to an attack against a smoke devil, it gains resist damage 16+ against the attack.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: Smoke devils drift and eddy as if blown by an evil wind.

traits.name: Resist fire 13+
traits.description: When a fire attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 13+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

traits.name: Free-form covert ability - Insinuate
traits.description: Smoke devils have a preternatural ability to get to their chosen victims. Keeping the smoke devil out is a hard, champion-tier challenge (DC 25).

specials.name: Smokey Retreat
specials.description: A smoke devil can “take 12” on disengage checks, taking a natural result of 12 instead of rolling (which normally would allow it to disengage automatically from up to two enemies).

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The target is hampered from burning eyes and gases in its lungs until the end of its next turn.

attacks.name: Peck & tear
attacks.hit: 8 damage, and until the end of the owlbear’s next turn, the target is hampered while engaged with the owlbear.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: Until the end of the snowy owlbear’s next turn, the target is hampered while engaged with the owlbear.

traits.name: New Trait
traits.description: A snowy owlbear that scores a critical hit against a hampered enemy tears a piece of the creature off (GM chooses a limb) and will subsequently attempt to retreat with the prize, screeching to its cubs to flee with it. The torn-up enemy is stunned until the end of its next turn.

traits.name: Protect the cubs
traits.description: The snowy owlbear’s crit range expands by 1 for each owlbear cub that has dropped this battle.

traits.name: Resist cold 14+
traits.description: Attacks that deal cold damage deal half damage to the snowy owlbear unless they roll a natural 14+.

traits.name: Resist cold 12+

extras.name: Natural even hit or miss
extras.description: The phoenix may move again this turn as a quick action if it has already made a flying move on its turn.

attacks.name: Solar wind
attacks.tag: Usually special trigger, but also possible as a standard action
attacks.attack: +17 vs. PD (1d4 nearby or faraway enemies)
attacks.hit: 70 fire damage, or 120 fire damage if used as a standard action.

extras.name: Natural even hit or miss
extras.description: The solar phoenix teleports to a point nearby or faraway.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: The solar phoenix flies like the sun unleashed.

traits.name: Flaming wings
traits.description: The solar phoenix deals 20 fire damage to each enemy that ends it turn engaged with the phoenix.

traits.name: Resist fire 16+
traits.description: When a fire attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 16+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

traits.name: Spectacular effects
traits.description: When the solar phoenix is dealt a critical hit, it must roll an easy save (6+). If the save fails, the phoenix drops to 0 hit points; see the reborn in fire ability below!

traits.name: Reborn in fire
traits.description:
Whenever the phoenix drops to 0 hit points, roll a /r d20 and add the escalation die. For each time this phoenix has rolled its reborn in fire ability earlier this battle, subtract 10 from the roll. For example, a phoenix making its second reborn in fire roll (because its first roll ended up being 20+!) when the escalation die is 6 would roll the d20 and subtract 4.

20+: The solar phoenix is immediately reborn, healing to 400 hit points and keeps fighting!

15–19: The phoenix is reborn in fire, but vaults into the overworld, removed from the battle. On the other hand, it’s not done with the PCs! Add the phoenix to an upcoming battle by surprise, adding it as an additional monster not accounted for by the usual encounter-building calculations.

8–14: The solar phoenix is reborn in fire but wants nothing more to do with this battle. It makes a conflagration of rebirth attack, but when the attack is over it shoots off into the overworld so quickly that it’s a teleport effect, and does not return to the battle, nor to the adventure. 

7 or less: The phoenix flares back to life somewhere nearby in a few hours, days, months, or years. Probably not relevant to the PCs unless they or the phoenix bear a special grudge. But who are we kidding? This is a solar phoenix. It has its own agenda, and the PCs just got onto the agenda, one way or another.

extras.name: Natural even hit, or any hit against a *weakened*, *stunned*, or *confused* target
extras.description: Randomly select one of the target’s limited-use powers or spells. The soul flenser flenses it away, removing it from the target until that creature regains it via a successful connection to the oversoul (see below).

extras.name: Natural 3, 6, or 9
extras.description: The target is confused (save ends).

attacks.name: C: Soul blast
attacks.attack: +14 vs. MD (1d4 nearby enemies in a group)

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The target is weakened (save ends).

extras.name: Natural odd hit
extras.description: If the target is already weakened, it’s also stunned until end of its next turn.

traits.name: Connection to the Oversoul
traits.description: When a creature slays a soul flenser, it can roll a hard save (16+). If it succeeds, the creature regains one power it has had flensed away.

traits.name: Intellect fortress
traits.description: When an enemy misses the soul flenser with an attack against MD, that attacker takes half the miss damage, if any.

traits.name: Underkraken teleport
traits.description: A soul flenser that has successfully flensed at least once can (and usually will, provided some of its enemies are confused, weakened, or stunned) use a standard action to prepare itself to teleport. Once it does this, during its next turn it can use a move action to teleport back to its home underkraken, no matter how distant, leaving the battle behind. Soul flensers fighting beside or within their underkraken can’t use this ability; they’re already home.

specials.name: Flensing escalator
specials.description: The soul flenser gains an attack bonus equal to the escalation die against creatures that have had one or more powers flensed away.

specials.name: Oversoul control
specials.description: While confused by a soul flenser’s effect, a creature that has had a power flensed away can use and re-use that limited power against their erstwhile allies, if the GM sees how to use the power in a useful way.

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: Each nearby enemy takes 10 thunder damage

attacks.name: Bloom of lightning

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: Each nearby enemy takes 10 thunder damage

attacks.name: Sparking aura

attacks.hit: 20 lightning damage, an the target is vulnerable (save ends).

traits.name: Arcane Mirror
traits.description: When an enemy targets the sparkscale naga with a spell, the naga regains the use of sparking aura if it’s expended. In addition, if that spell is a recharge spell, roll its recharge check immediately after the spell is cast. If the spell is a per-battle or daily spell, roll a hard save (16+) immediately after the spell is cast; on a success, the spellcaster doesn’t expend the spell.

traits.name: Mystic escalator
traits.description: The naga and each of its nearby allies can use the escalation die unless the naga has been targeted by an enemy’s spell since its last turn.

extras.name: Natural 18+
extras.description: If the target is staggered, it is also hampered (makes only basic attacks) until the end of its next turn.

extras.name: Natural even hit or miss

traits.name: Punishing aura
traits.description: When an enemy attacks the specter and misses, it takes 8 negative energy damage.

traits.name: Wrack and ruin
traits.description: While a specter is in the battle, the PCs don’t add the escalation die to attack rolls, but it does.

attacks.name: Negating strike

extras.name: Natural roll is above target’s Intelligence
extras.description: The target is hampered (hard save ends, 16+) instead.

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: 1d2 random magic items on the target are also affected. One-shot items like potions and oils are ruined; true magic items lose their default bonus and any powers until the end of the battle.

extras.name: Limited use
extras.description: 2/battle.

traits.name: Limited golem immunity
traits.description: A golem warder can’t be dazed, weakened, confused, or made vulnerable. Ongoing damage doesn’t harm it either, unless it’s acid, fire, or lightning.

traits.name: Spell deflection
traits.description:
When a spell attack targets the mage hunter, roll a .

On a 1–7, the attack or effect hits normally.

On an 8–15, the attack or effect is negated.

On a 16+, the attack or effect is reflected back at the caster as if that enemy had been targeted instead of the golem (so it must overcome defenses and resistances, as normal).

specials.name: Made of tougher stuff
specials.description: Instead of wood, stronger materials were used to create the golem, such as crystal or brass. This golem is non-organic and has golem immunity (so ongoing acid, fire, and lightning don't harm it).

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The target is dazed until the end of its next turn.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The warder pops free from each enemy engaged with it and can move as a free action, usually next to an ally.

traits.name: Limited golem immunity
traits.description: A golem warder can’t be dazed, weakened, confused, or made vulnerable. Ongoing damage doesn’t harm it either, unless it’s acid, fire, or lightning.

traits.name: Protect the master
traits.description: While the golem warder is next to an ally, once per round when a melee attack targets that ally, it can try to intercept the attack as a free action. Roll an easy save (6+); if it succeeds, the warder becomes the target of the attack instead.

traits.name: Spellward
traits.description:
Twice per battle when a spell attack hits a nearby ally, the warder can have the attack target itself instead as an interrupt action. If the attack roll doesn’t hit against the warder’s defenses, the attack misses. Otherwise, the warder takes all damage and effects of the spell for that ally. When the warder takes damage this way, it can make an *empowered slam* attack during its next turn.

Golem warders are usually linked to a master through a ritual. Unless instructed otherwise, they use spellward only to protect that master.

specials.name: Hard to destroy
specials.description: Only natural even spell attack rolls deal damage to the golem.

attacks.name: C: Web
attacks.attack: +11 vs. PD (up to 2 nearby enemies in a group)

traits.name: Wall-crawler
traits.description: A spider mount can climb on ceilings and walls as easily as it moves on the ground, and so can its rider.

traits.name: Uncontrolled
traits.description: A riderless spider mount will eventually run away. At the start of the spider’s turn roll a d4; if you roll less than the escalation die, the mount flees.

extras.name: Hit and natural attack roll exceeds target’s Dexterity

attacks.hit: The target chooses one: it takes 6d6 psychic damage; OR as a free action, it moves next to the spinneret doxy (possibly provoking opportunity attacks), who engages it

attacks.name: C: Stop in the name of love
attacks.hit: The target chooses one: it takes 6d6 psychic damage; OR it’s stuck (save ends)

traits.name: Infatuated

They also prattle on about how their friends shouldn’t attack her, but are too love-smitten to properly prevent it—they won’t attack their real allies.

traits.name: Give me your heart
traits.description: When the doxy drops an enemy to 0 hit points or lower, she will move next to that creature and attempt to remove the target’s heart. The creature must begin making last gasp saves as she cuts their chest open. On the fourth failure, the doxy takes the heart and the target dies and becomes undead under her control. If the bride is stunned or moved away from the creature and can’t return to it on her turn, the creature doesn’t have to make a last gasp save that turn.

extras.name: Natural 16+

traits.name: Impossible teleport
traits.description: When the splotchcap scores a critical hit OR when a PC or a player at the table says the bad word, the splotchcap can teleport to a nearby hidden location it can see as a free action.

traits.name: Pop-out surprise

traits.name: Hidden guardian
traits.description: If a spriggan wants to stay hidden in an illusory form instead of joining a battle, roll initiative for the spriggan as normal. When the spriggan “acts,” by doing nothing, have the most perceptive PC roll a DC 25 Wisdom check, adding +1 for each of their allies in the fight. On a success, the spriggan’s illusion is pierced and the spriggan can use a single move action during its turn, but nothing else—it burned its standard action trying to stay hidden.

traits.name: Embiggen
traits.description: When the escalation die reaches 2, the spriggan grows in size as a free action, acquiring its giant-sized slap attack. Note that as a free action, this transformation can take place any time, usually at the start of a round. If the spriggan was using its hidden guardian ability, it’s not hidden anymore!

traits.name: Fluttering
traits.description: The sprite flies, but never too far from the ground.

traits.name: Power of a name
traits.description: This creature gains different abilities based on which name it has taken.

traits.name: Pixie
traits.description: When the sprite scores a critical hit with its whispered song attack, instead of taking damage, the target falls unconscious (save ends).

traits.name: Grig
traits.description: When the sprite rolls a natural odd hit with its whispered song attack, the target loses its next move action as it begins dancing uncontrollably.

attacks.name: Tearing claws
attacks.hit: 18 damage as the stalker rakes its victim with its clawed feet

specials.name: Surprise!
specials.description: Despite its size, as an ambush hunter, the stalker is very good at shadowing its prey. Checks to notice it and avoid surprise are ridiculously hard.

extras.name: Instant rebirth
extras.description: Any enemy that dies due to ongoing damage from mutagenic emanations instantly rejoins the fight as a star-mask brain zealot allied to the dungeon heart.

attacks.name: C: Sickly sweet feelings
attacks.attack: +22 vs. MD (one nearby or faraway enemy)
attacks.hit: Until the end of the battle, the next time the target drops to 0 hp or below, the target recovers with temporary hit points equal to its normal maximum hit points, but is now an ally to the dungeon heart. It is a standard action to free an ally next to you from their *sickly sweet feelings*, but doing so makes them lose their temporary hp (at which point they’ll collapse again unless they have been somehow healed above 0 hit points).

extras.name: Quick use
extras.description: 1/round, as a quick action.

attacks.name: R: Mind-erasing blast

traits.name: Mental scream
traits.description: The first time the dungeon heart is staggered, it makes a *mind-erasing blast* attack.

traits.name: Lost opportunity
traits.description: The dungeon heart can’t make opportunity attacks.

traits.name: Neuralogenic
traits.description: The brain doesn’t move about by itself, but it does infect nearby matter, turning wherever it is into more of itself: if you are close enough to fight the brain, you are de-facto engaged with it, and will be affected by its *mutagenic emanations* attack.

specials.name: Flesh absorption
specials.description: When an enemy fails to save against the ongoing damage from mutagenic emanations, the dungeon heart heals 20 hp.

specials.name: Soul drain
specials.description: Enemies killed by the dungeon heart become mindless living husks with no resurrection or healing possible—their soul is gone. (Of course, there may be some miraculous quest for healing magic that could restore them.)

attacks.name: Phasing tentacles
attacks.attack: (automatic hit against each enemy engaged with it)
attacks.hit: 30 damage, and the target pops free from it

attacks.name: R: Phased blast
attacks.hit: 25 force damage, and 25 ongoing damage (hard save ends 16+, or using a standard action to restore equilibrium also ends)

traits.name: Warpwalk
traits.description: While the escalation die is odd, the star-mask brain zealot can’t be intercepted, doesn’t suffer opportunity attacks, and takes only half damage from attacks that target AC or PD.

attacks.name: Mind-linking tentacles
attacks.hit: The target is confused until the end of its next turn

attacks.name: C: Astral tentacles
attacks.attack: +12 vs. MD (1d3 closest nearby or faraway enemies)
attacks.hit: 10 psychic damage, and the target is dazed (save ends)

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The target is confused (save ends) instead of dazed.

extras.name: Hit against a target that has been confused and saved against it this battle
extras.description: 20 psychic damage, but no dazed or confused effect.

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The star-mask brute can make a throw attack against the target as a free action.

attacks.name: Throw
attacks.hit: The target is thrown faraway, takes 20 damage, and is weakened (easy save ends, 6+).

attacks.name: Mark of the stars
attacks.hit: 21 psychic damage, and the target is marked with a glowing rune (hard save ends, 16+). While the target is marked this way, the cult leader’s allies gain a +1 attack bonus and +3 damage bonus against it. A creature can have only one mark at a time.

attacks.name: R: Psychic domination
attacks.hit: 18 psychic damage, and 18 ongoing psychic damage

extras.name: Natural even hit or miss
extras.description: One dead (or unconscious or otherwise out of the fight) star-mask cultist, dead star-mask cult leader, or dead star-mask brute becomes a living scuttling star-mask mook.

attacks.name: C: Tentacle whip
attacks.hit: 15 damage, and the target pops free from each enemy engaged with it and is pulled into engagement with the star-mask puppet

traits.name: Psychic coordination
traits.description: For every star-mask puppet engaged with an enemy, other star-masks not engaged with that enemy gain a +1 attack bonus against that enemy (maximum +4).

traits.name: Wall-crawler
traits.description: The star-mask puppet can use oily tentacles to climb on ceilings and walls as easily as it moves on the ground.

traits.name: Psychic chaff
traits.description: Star-mask parasites that create puppets quickly die and fade to dust after their puppet drops to 0 hp. After a battle against star-mask puppets, each character must roll a hard save (16+). If they fail, they remember only the host body and not the white mask and black tentacles that were embedded in its flesh. Even characters who succeed find it hard to keep the memory of the star-mask in mind afterward, potentially making for confusing battles against these puppets.

attacks.name: C: Psychic blast
attacks.attack: +10 vs. MD (1d3 nearby enemies, or faraway enemies in a group)

extras.name: Limited use
extras.description: 1/round, as a quick action when the escalation die is odd.

traits.name: Group ability
traits.description: For every two star-mask cultists in the battle (round up), one of them can use coordinated attack once as a free action during the battle.

traits.name: Coordinated attack (group)
traits.description: Until the start of its next turn, the star-mask cultist gains a +2 attack bonus against enemies that are engaged with the cultist’s allies.

specials.name: New host
specials.description: When this cultist drops to 0 hp, a new scuttling star-mask joins the battle (in the same location as the dead cultist) and immediately makes a suffocating thoughts attack as a free action against the closest enemy.

attacks.name: C: Psychic pulse
attacks.hit: 18 psychic damage, and the target is hampered until the end of the floating brain’s next turn

extras.name: If the target was already hampered
extras.description: The floating brain’s crit range expands to 11+ for the attack.

traits.name: Group ability
traits.description: For every three star-mask floating brains in the battle (round up), one of them can use psychic puppetry once during the battle.

traits.name: Psychic puppetry (group)
traits.description: When a star-mask floating brain scores a critical hit with psychic pulse, instead of dealing extra damage, the target becomes confused (save ends) instead of hampered.

traits.name: Hovering brain
traits.description: The brain uses telepathic energy to float in the air at about head height.

traits.name: Lost opportunity
traits.description: Star-mask floating brains can’t make opportunity attacks.

extras.name: Target fails a save against the ongoing psychic damage
extras.description: At the start of the target’s next turn, it must use its move action to engage the omnipotent brain. It won’t take opportunity attacks to do so, instead trying to disengage.

attacks.name: C: Psionic supremacy
attacks.attack: +17 vs. MD (one nearby or faraway enemy)

extras.name: Aftereffect
extras.description: When the target saves against the ongoing damage, it must choose one: it makes a basic attack against itself or an ally with its next standard action, OR it becomes weakened until the end of its next turn.

extras.name: Natural 1–5
extras.description: The target is immune to the aftereffect of psionic supremacy until the end of the battle.

extras.name: Limited use
extras.description: 2/round, as separate quick actions.

traits.name: Crawling brain
traits.description: The brain can crawl about on tentacles but prefers to use its telekinetic grasp to move enemies toward it or its allies.

traits.name: Psychic contamination
traits.description: Creatures engaged with the star-mask omnipotent brain that have 120 hp or fewer can’t target the omnipotent brain with attacks.

traits.name: Telekinetic grasp
traits.description: As a move action the brain can move an ally or enemy, causing them to fly about. An enemy can roll a save to avoid being moved against its will. If it succeeds, there’s no effect. Enemies hurled against solid objects or other allies take 2d20 damage, or possibly more if hurled into dangerous terrain.

traits.name: Absorb
traits.description: When an enemy engaged with the star-mask brain omnipotent rolls a natural 1–5 on a disengage check, it’s absorbed into the omnipotent brain’s flesh. Absorbed characters are stuck, weakened, and move with the omnipotent (hard save ends all, 16+). Creatures can also be freed from an omnipotent brain’s flesh with a DC 30 skill check as a standard action. If the check fails by 5 or more, the assisting ally is also now absorbed with the same effects.

traits.name: Perceptual warp
traits.description: When an enemy targets the omnipotent brain with a ranged attack and rolls a natural 1–5, it must reroll the attack against an ally engaged with the brain, if any, as if it had fumbled.

traits.name: Psychic command
traits.description: The omnipotent brain can use a standard action to allow a nearby ally to make an attack as a free action with a +4 attack bonus. If the ally misses it takes 1d8 damage and the brain heals 50 hp.

attacks.name: Claws
attacks.hit: 2 damage, and the stirge can make a draining probe attack against the target during its next turn if it’s still engaged with the target

attacks.name: Draining probe
attacks.attack: +7 vs. AC (1 enemy hit by claws last turn)

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: Stirges fly well. Also, the pitch of their wings is high and thin, allowing a stirge to get very close without tipping off its prey.

specials.name: One and done
specials.description: After hitting a living creature that has blood with its draining probe attack, the stirge heals 5 hit points and will use its next turn to move, fleeing to the hive to feed the stirgelings…and to alert the hive that there is an easy meal nearby. A new full-strength stirge enters the battle during the next round on the same initiative count.

attacks.name: Claws
attacks.hit: The effect depends on the roll

extras.name: Natural odd hit
extras.description: 2 damage.

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: Choose one effect, and then the stirgeling mob takes 4 damage (killing this creature first).

traits.name: Regular stirgeling
traits.description: The target takes 3 damage, and 3 ongoing damage.

traits.name: Archer stirgeling
traits.description: The target takes 6 damage.

traits.name: Cobbler stirgeling
traits.description: The target takes 3 damage and is stuck until end of its next turn.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description: They aren’t strong fliers but they are quick and agile.

extras.name: Natural even hit or miss
extras.description: The stone giant can also make a stomp attack against a single target as a free action.

attacks.name: Stomp
attacks.attack: +13 vs. PD (each smaller enemy engaged with the giant)
attacks.hit: 30 damage, and the target is dazed (save ends)

attacks.attack: +11 vs. PD (1 nearby or far away enemy)

extras.name: Natural even miss
extras.description: 20 damage.

traits.name: Built of stone
traits.description: The stone giant has resist weapons 16+.

attacks.hit: 80 damage, and the golem pops the target off it and moves it a short distance away from the golem

extras.name: Natural even hit or miss
extras.description: 20 damage, and the target is hampered (save ends).

extras.name: Natural odd hit or miss
extras.description: 20 damage, and the target is dazed (save ends).

traits.name: Golem immunity
traits.description: Non-organic golems are immune to effects. They can’t be dazed, weakened, confused, made vulnerable, or touched by ongoing damage. You can damage a golem, but that’s about it.

specials.name: Former idol
specials.description: Evoke the powers of an ancient culture’s strange rites by giving the stone golem any weird power you wish. If you’re stuck for inspiration, consider starting with random abilities from the demons that aren’t related to energy or the cone of cold from the ogre mage.

extras.name: Natural even hit or miss
extras.description: The giant can make a lightning bolt attack against a random nearby enemy as a free action.

attacks.name: R: Giant longbow
attacks.attack: +14 vs. AC (2 attacks vs. nearby or far away enemies)

extras.name: Natural even hit
extras.description: The giant can make a lightning bolt attack against a random enemy that is nearby the target of the longbow attack.

attacks.name: C: Release the thunder
attacks.hit: 1d10 thunder damage per building thunder point (see below).

traits.name: Building thunder
traits.description: Keep count of the number of times the storm giant uses its lightning bolt attack during the battle. Add that number to the escalation die to get the current building thunder value.

traits.name: Skystep
traits.description: A storm giant can use its standard action to walk or run through the air, using move actions to continue. If the storm giant makes a standard action attack, it settles back to the ground below it without falling.

traits.name: Storm born
traits.description: The storm giant has resist thunder 16+ and resist lightning 16+.

attacks.name: Wicked claws
attacks.hit: 7 damage, and the target is vulnerable (save ends)

attacks.name: Shivering blade
attacks.hit: 25 negative energy damage, or 50 negative energy damage if the target has been hit by at least one sundering attack earlier in the battle

attacks.name: C: Sundering

traits.name: Enormously bulky
traits.description: The tarrasque is so huge that it ignores opportunity attacks. In addition, normal-sized enemies are like fleas to it, and disengaging from the tarrasque requires only an easy save (6+), unless the target is grabbed.

traits.name: Inmortal
traits.description: The tarrasque can’t be killed, save by the explicit will of a god (and not some jumped-up local god, either) or, perhaps, the sacrifice of a great icon. The tarrasque’s HP total indicates the amount of damage required to make it disgorge swallowed enemies and flee to go hibernate while it regenerates the damage it suffered and decide if it wants to rampage again.

traits.name: Legendary Resistance
traits.description: The tarrasque is immune to normal conditions and effects (stunned, weakened, etc.), but it isn’t completely impervious. Bypassing its resistances requires icon-supported effort. A PC can use one 5 or 6 they acquired from icon relationship dice rolls to overcome the resistance each time they use an attack or power that would apply a condition or effect upon the tarrasque. Of course, they must also provide a story to go along with the reason the tarrasque is affected.

traits.name: Leveler
traits.description: When the escalation die is even, as a move action the tarrasque can demolish any ordinary structure it can reach, such as a house, castle wall, temple, or ship. The beast automatically reduces the structure to rubble, rendering it useless. Each creature on top of or within the structure is subject to a collapse attack.

traits.name: Swallow Whole
traits.description: Once a creature is swallowed, it goes inside one of the tarrasque’s gigantic stomachs. It can still act while inside the tarrasque, but it will have to deal with the beast’s stomach acid that is splashing around. A swallowed creature must deal 400 damage to the tarrasque to force it to disgorge the contents of its gullet, freeing the creature. During the tarrasque’s turn, it can make a gullet digestion attack against the target as a free action.

traits.name: Soft-ish innerbelly
traits.description: The tarrasque doesn’t have scales on the inside. It takes a –5 penalty to all defenses against attacks from inside its gullet, though only melee and close attacks can be made in there. The tarrasque’s insides are immune to acid damage, however.

specials.name: Fear
specials.description: While engaged with the tarrasque, enemies that have 216 hp or fewer are dazed (–4 attack) and do not add the escalation die to their attacks.

specials.name: Regeneration 230
specials.description: While a tarrasque is damaged, its malign magical flesh heals 230 hit points at the start of the tarrasque’s turn. It can regenerate five times per battle. If it heals up to its maximum hit points, then that use of regeneration doesn’t count against the five-use limit. With this power, the monstrosity is likely unstoppable without a powerful magical artifact designed specifically to bind, wound, or otherwise hamper the tarrasque.

traits.description: Each enemy that has one or more icon relationship points with the Demonic Icon that misses an attack with a natural odd roll takes a -2 penalty to all its defenses until the end of the battle.

traits.name: Bound hauntings
traits.description:
Most ghosts are bound to an area, usually the area of their death. This ability won’t come up much in play, but it does make it seem likely that ghosts can be easier to get away from than other monsters. Move far enough fast enough and the ghost returns to the area it’s bound to. Occasionally festivals for the dead or other rituals can call bound ghosts from their hauntings, but those are unusual and temporary circumstances.

Exceptions: There may be ghosts that are bound to people, or events, or phenomena that travel. There might even be ghosts that aren’t bound to anything, but at that stage there are several other questions that surface and odd magical, iconic, or unique intervention seems likely.

traits.name: Flight
traits.description:
Most ghosts fly, though some may be quite slow, seeming to drift or walking on air. Ghosts that fly in unusual ways will be flagged with their own abilities.

Exceptions: Not all ghosts fly. Some seem constrained to act much like they acted when they were alive, and flying wasn’t part of their life package.

traits.name: Unnatural touch
traits.description:
Many ghosts can alter the temperature of their environment to more closely match the underworld or afterlife that they’ve so far evaded. Sometimes that’s icy cold, sometimes that’s burning hot, and sometimes it’s just kind of normal, which would go unnoticed unless the ghost is somewhere abnormal!

Exceptions: This is more of a special effect of ghost stories than part of a creature’s combat abilities, and you can safely ignore it unless you find telling moments when it adds to the game.

Whenever the phoenix drops to 0 hit points, roll a /r d20 and add the escalation die. For each time this void phoenix has rolled its reborn in void ability earlier this battle, subtract 10 from the roll. For example, a void phoenix making its second reborn in void roll (because its first roll ended up being 20+!) when the escalation die is 6 would roll the d20 and subtract 4.

20+: The void phoenix is immediately reborn, healing to 120 hit points above staggered and keeps fighting!

15–19: The void phoenix is reborn in a blast of cold and fire and negative energy, but vaults into the overworld, removed from the battle. On the other hand, it’s not done with the PCs! Add the phoenix to an upcoming battle by surprise, adding it as an additional monster not accounted for by the usual encounter- building calculations. Add a level if you feel like it, because it’s angry.

8–14: The void phoenix is reborn in a blast of negative energy but wants nothing more to do with this battle. It makes a void rebirth attack, but when the attack is over it shoots off into the overworld so quickly that it’s a teleport effect, and does not return to the battle, nor to the adventure.

7 or less: The phoenix flares back to life somewhere nearby in a few hours, days, months, or years. Probably not relevant to the PCs unless they or the phoenix bear a special grudge.

specials.name: Final-gasp soul snatch & escape
specials.description:
When the devil drops to 0 hp, it appears dead until the start of its next turn, at which point it will attempt to steal a piece of the soul of the closest character before it escapes into a supernatural bolt hole. That character must roll a save. If they fail, they lose a chunk of their soul—see below for possible effects. Anyone who uses a coup de grace on the devil before its next turn will slay it before it can claim a chunk of a soul and escape (but the PCs might not be aware of this).

Effects: What does it mean to have a chunk of your soul stolen. You’re free to come up with complications that suit your campaign’s metaphysics or take the suggestions that follow as a starting point. Use one or more, as you choose.

  • Magic items no longer work for the affected character, even ones already attuned to them, and in a similar vein, no new items can be attuned by that PC.
  • The PC loses access to their highest level of spells or powers. For example, a cleric who normally casts 7th level spells could only cast them at 5th level.
  • The PC takes a –2 penalty to saves.
  • The PC must roll 2d20 for attack rolls and take the lowest result for the first two rounds of each battle.
  • The PC’s appearance changes in some disturbing, hollow way and they take a –4 penalty to skill checks.
  • PC loses one to three recoveries; not temporarily, their ability to heal decreases.
  • One icon relationship changes to become a sign of complications with devils, not advantages.
  • Devils gets some huge combat advantage against the PC.

Restoration: Similarly, you can choose how the missing piece of soul might be restored. Some examples:

  • No big deal: the PC rolls a normal save each time they gain a level. If the save succeeds, they get their soul back.
  • The party must find and kill the escaped hubris devil. Luckily, the PC’s ‘link’ to the devil means that each day the PC can roll a normal save; on an 11+, they have a good idea of which direction the devil is in. And hubris devils don’t move all that much.
  • Instead, the party must travel to the center of the devils’ power and steal back their friend’s soul shard. Or whatever it is that you think their particular soul piece is gonna look like.
  • The devils immediately barter the soul shard to an enemy icon, leading to an entirely new set of quests and complications.

attacks.name: C: A truly wild ride
attacks.hit: The victim is drawn to the waterhorse in its black charger form and happily mounts the beast (treat it as a teleport for simplicity’s sake). Once they are astride, the waterhorse attempts to flee into the nearest body of water, taking the rider with them. To prevent this, the rider can attempt a DC 25 Strength-based control check as a quick action (1d20 + level + Strength modifier + any relevant background + escalation die). If they succeed, the rider gains control of the creature and can either dismount or steer it to where they wish, potentially with a view to stealing its bridle on their next turn (requiring a successful attack roll with that specified aim). If the rider does not attempt to steal the bridle on their next turn, they must make another DC 25 check to remain in control. Stealing the bridle turns the waterhorse into its humanoid form and throws the rider clear. If the rider fails to control the creature at any point, it converts its next standard action to a move action, using it and any other move actions it may have to enter the water and trigger its watery grave attack 1 round later. The rider can continue to make control checks until watery grave is activated.

attacks.name: C: Watery words
attacks.hit: The target is confused (save ends; see *the river’s song* below)

traits.name: The river’s song
traits.description: When a creature is confused from the naiad’s watery words attack, it immediately moves into the water next to the naiad as a free action to defend the naiad. The target takes half the damage of the next attack that hits the naiad. During its turn, it doesn’t attack, instead moving to stay next to the naiad. Each time the target fails its save, it will again defend the naiad against the next attack that hits it, taking half damage.

traits.name: One with the river
traits.description: A naiad can walk on the surface of water, making it seem shallow, and it can swim through the water and breathe underwater with ease. Its enemies might have a more difficult time engaging it.

traits.name: Domain bound
traits.description: Nymphs are tied to an area of land or water. Land areas will be at most a couple miles wide; water areas might be much larger. As a rule, nymphs can’t leave the area they’re bound to.

traits.name: Limited immortality
traits.description: A nymph that drops to 0 hit points or is otherwise slain will eventually return to life in its domain, so long as its domain and its secret survives. After an hour, a nymph needs a hard save to return to life. After eight hours, a nymph needs a normal save to return to life. If the nymph has still not returned, roll an easy save at the end of each 24 hours until the nymph succeeds.

traits.name: Note on types
traits.description: Nymphs with the humanoid type probably remember themselves. Nymphs that have probably forgotten their original selves have the elemental type.

specials.name: Naiad’s cleansing
specials.description: Each time a target confused by watery words fails its save, it will forget something important. GM’s choice or player’s suggestion!

attacks.attack: +12 vs. PD (1d3 nearby enemies in a group)
attacks.hit: 24 damage, and the target loses its next move action

extras.name: Escalation die is 3+
extras.description: The attack targets 1d3 +1 nearby enemies in a group instead.

specials.description: When a weapon attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 14+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

attacks.name: Fang, claw, or tusk
attacks.hit: 21 damage, and the beast’s special ability triggers

traits.name: Armored polar bear
traits.description: The target takes 10 extra damage, and if the target makes an opportunity attack against the polar bear before the start of the bear’s next turn, the bear can make a fang, claw, or tusk attack against the target as a free action.

traits.name: Giant walrus
traits.description: The target takes 14 extra damage and is stuck (save ends; also ends if the walrus moves)

traits.name: Winter wolf
traits.description: The target takes 14 extra damage, or 28 extra damage if another winter wolf is engaged with it.

traits.name: Resist cold 12+
traits.description: When a cold attack targets this creature, the attacker must roll a natural 12+ on the attack roll or it only deals half damage.

traits.name: Pack attack
traits.description: This creature gains a +2 bonus to attack and damage for each other ally engaged with the target (max +4 bonus).

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The save is hard (16+) instead.

extras.name: Environmental boost
extras.description: The dryad gains a +4 bonus to the attack against targets that have consumed natural food or water within the dryad’s domain within the last day.

traits.name: Tree stride
traits.description: As a move action, a dryad can enter any living tree within its domain it’s touching and teleport to another tree within that region. This movement doesn’t provoke opportunity attacks.

specials.name: Call tree friends
specials.description: Before the start of the battle, the dryad summons 2d4 awakened trees that fight with it.

specials.name: Entrancing beauty
specials.description: The dryad can appear as a beautiful wood elf. While speaking with creatures outside of battle, the dryad can choose to add power to its words to try to charm those listening. Make a willowy words attack against each creature that can hear the dryad. On a hit, instead of being confused, the target is charmed (as per the charm person spell). It then considers the dryad a friend. Creatures missed by the attackonly notice the charm attempt if it misses by 4 or more. A dryad can attempt to charm a creature only once per day.

specials.name: Woodland grace
specials.description: The dryad can take an extra standard action during its turn when the escalation die is even.

attacks.name: Ghostly fangs
attacks.hit: 25 negative energy damage, and the target takes +1d8 negative energy damage for each relationship point it has with the bat’s associated icon.

attacks.name: C: Spiraling assault
attacks.hit: 22 negative energy damage, and after the attack the wraith bat teleports to and engages with one target it hit.

traits.name: Ghostly
traits.description: This creature has resist damage 16+ to all damage except force damage, which damages it normally. A wraith bat can move through solid objects but it can’t end its movement inside them.

extras.name: Natural 16+
extras.description: The target is also weakened (save ends).
